questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with two days of worsening abdominal pain in the lower left quadrant. There is associated decreased appetite, constipation, and frequent urination. The patient has not experienced weight loss, diarrhea, or blood in the stools. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type II. The patient has a 20-pack-year smoking history and a diet consisting mainly of red meat. BMI is 30 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 38.5 °C (101.3 °F), blood pressure is 137/75 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and room air oxygen saturation is 97%. Abdominal examination is significant for left lower quadrant tenderness with guarding. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis and an elevated CRP. Urinalysis shows pyuria. Which findings will most likely be seen with further diagnostic studies?

choices.text: Multiple colonic inflamed diverticula with localized bowel wall thickening and pericolonic fat stranding on CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Growth of E. coli from the urine culture
Mucosal and chronic submucosal inflammation, erosion/ulceration, and crypt abscesses on histopathological examination of the colon
Dilated appendix with localized bowel wall thickening and periappendiceal fat stranding on CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Left solid ovarian mass with thick septations on pelvic ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has acute diverticulitis, characterized by diverticulum inflammation due to micro-perforation and bacterial seeding in the diverticulum wall. It most commonly occurs in Western societies in the sigmoid colon, where there is the highest intraluminal pressure. Risk factors for acute diverticulitis include older age, obesity, a diet high in red meat and low in fiber, a sedentary lifestyle, and aspirin and NSAID use. Patients with acute diverticulitis usually report acute, constant, crampy abdominal pain localized to the left lower quadrant. Other symptoms include fevers [typically below 39°C (102 °F)], nausea, change in bowel habits (e.g., constipation, diarrhea), and urinary symptoms (e.g., dysuria, urinary frequency, and urgency) due to bladder irritation from the inflamed sigmoid colon. Abdominal examination typically shows hypoactive bowel sounds and tenderness localized to the LLQ.

Laboratory evaluation typically shows leukocytosis with a left shift and an elevated CRP. The most appropriate test for diagnosis is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast (water-soluble if perforation is suspected), which can show areas of inflamed diverticula with localized thickening of the bowel wall, pericolonic fat stranding, and potential findings of complications of acute diverticulitis (e.g., abscess, fistula, obstruction, perforation). Other laboratory findings may include sterile pyuria if urinary symptoms are present.  

Option Analysis

✅ Multiple colonic inflamed diverticula with localized bowel wall thickening and pericolonic fat stranding on CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Growth of E. coli from the urine culture:
Incorrect: Urinary frequency and pyuria, as seen in this patient, can occur with acute diverticulitis when there is irritation of the bladder from the inflamed sigmoid colon. The cause of this patient’s lower left quadrant abdominal pain, constipation, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers is likely acute diverticulitis with associated irritation of the bladder, not a urinary tract infection.  
❌ Mucosal and chronic submucosal inflammation, erosion/ulceration, and crypt abscesses on histopathological examination of the colon:
Incorrect: These histopathological findings are consistent with a diagnosis of ulcerative colitis. The acute onset of the abdominal pain and the absence of diarrhea and blood in the stool make this diagnosis less likely.  
❌ Dilated appendix with localized bowel wall thickening and periappendiceal fat stranding on CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This finding on a CT scan indicates acute appendicitis. Although acute appendicitis can present with abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis, the localization of this patient’s abdominal pain on the left side makes acute diverticulitis more likely.  
❌ Left solid ovarian mass with thick septations on pelvic ultrasound:
Incorrect: This finding on pelvic ultrasound would suggest ovarian cancer. Although ovarian cancer can present with abdominal pain, the acute onset of her symptoms, the presence of fever, leukocytosis, elevated CRP, and the absence of weight loss make ovarian cancer less likely.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for severe lower left quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting that started abruptly two days ago. The patient had a fever of 38.4°C (101.1 ºF) at home and has not had a bowel movement since the symptoms started. There is no weight loss, diarrhea, or dysuria. The patient had a similar episode a year ago that resolved with dietary modifications and bowel rest. The patient was treated one month ago with ciprofloxacin for acute pyelonephritis. Temperature is 38.3 °C (100.9 °F), blood pressure is 119/76 mmHg, pulse is 91/min, and respirations are 20/min. The patient appears uncomfortable. Bowel sounds are hypoactive, and the abdomen is distended and tender to palpation in the left lower quadrant. Serum white blood cell count and CRP are elevated. Which of the following studies should be ordered to diagnose this patient’s underlying condition?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast
Clostridioides difficile stool antigen and toxin

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 2-day history of left lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation, fever, and signs of systemic inflammation. The most likely diagnosis is acute diverticulitis, likely complicated by significant bowel obstruction.

Uncomplicated diverticulitis results only in inflammation of the diverticula. Complicated diverticulitis is associated with frank perforation, peritonitis, obstruction, abscess, stricture, or fistula formation (most commonly colovesical or colovaginal).

The most appropriate test for diagnosing and classifying acute diverticulitis as uncomplicated versus complicated is a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast (water-soluble if perforation is suspected). In uncomplicated diverticulitis, a CT scan reveals inflamed diverticula with localized thickening of the bowel wall and pericolonic fat stranding. In complicated diverticulitis, the CT scan can show signs of frank perforation [free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum)], fistula formation (air bubbles within the bladder in colovesical fistula), abscess formation (fluid collection consistent with an abscess), bowel obstruction (dilated bowel loops with air-fluid levels and a transition point), or stricture formation. This classification can help in choosing the appropriate management.  

Option Analysis

✅ CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Urinalysis and urine culture:
Incorrect: Urinalysis and urine culture are used to diagnose acute cystitis. Urinary symptoms and pyuria on urinalysis can be seen with acute diverticulitis from bladder irritation from the inflamed sigmoid colon. This patient’s presentation of left lower quadrant abdominal pain, alteration of bowel habits, and fever support acute diverticulitis.  
❌ Clostridioides difficile stool antigen and toxin:
Incorrect: Stool antigen and toxin studies are used to diagnose C. difficile infection. Although this patient has risk factors for C. difficile infection (fluoroquinolone treatment), the absence of diarrhea makes this diagnosis less likely.  
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy is used to diagnose colorectal cancer, which can present with abdominal pain and alteration in bowel habits and can be an underlying cause of recurrent acute diverticulitis. Colonoscopy is contraindicated in the acute setting of diverticulitis due to the increased risk of perforation. It should be deferred until the complete resolution of symptoms (in six to eight weeks) to rule out underlying malignancy.  
❌ Plain abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: A plain abdominal radiograph can be used to diagnose bowel obstruction. Although this patient may have significant bowel obstruction presenting with nausea, vomiting, and distended abdomen, it is likely caused by underlying acute diverticulitis.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for sudden and severe abdominal pain, which began abruptly the evening prior to admission. There is associated hematochezia and she states she has a “fluttering sensation” in the chest. Past medical history includes diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and a myocardial infarction five years ago. Temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 85/63 mmHg, pulse is 132/min, and O2 saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination shows a pale, ill-appearing woman with diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation. The patient's ECG is shown below. Which of the following is the next best step in management?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe abdominal pain and hematochezia in the setting of new-onset atrial fibrillation. This picture is consistent with ischemic colitis. The associated hypotension suggests an unstable presentation of this disease process that should be addressed first by administering intravenous fluids like lactated Ringer solution.

Ischemic colitis refers to reduced intestinal blood flow, usually due to small vessel occlusion (e.g. from a thromboembolism) or hypoperfusion of the colon. Patients typically present with worsening cramping abdominal pain, tenesmus, bloody diarrhea, and hematochezia. Atrial fibrillation, such as in this patient, can cause thromboembolic events. Other risk factors include diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and recent aortic surgery (due to cross-clamping).

Unstable patients with ischemic colitis typically present more than 24 hours after the onset of initial signs and symptoms like acute abdominal pain, and at that point they may have signs of peritonitis, hypotension, and tachycardia. Acute management of ischemic colitis presenting with hypotension involves airway stabilization, establishing intravenous access, and administration of intravenous fluids.

Once stabilized, patients should be given intravenous antibiotics and undergo abdominal radiography to evaluate for the presence of dilation, pneumoperitoneum, portal venous gas, or pneumatosis coli. The presence of any one of these findings confirms the diagnosis of complicated ischemic colitis infarction. These patients require emergent surgical consultation for emergent laparotomy.

Option Analysis

✅ Administer lactated Ringer solution:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Antibiotic therapy is indicated for treating unstable ischemic colitis; however, this patient's hypotension should be addressed first by administering intravenous fluids.  
❌ Intubate the patient:
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette is speaking to the provider, implying airway protection. Endotracheal intubation is not indicated at this time.  
❌ Obtain surgical consultation:
Incorrect: While the surgical team should be consulted for this patient presenting with suspected ischemic colitis, addressing this patient’s hypotension takes precedence.  
❌ Administer norepinephrine:
Incorrect: This patient should receive fluid resuscitation as a first-line measure to treat hypotension. If hypotension is refractory to intravenous fluids (i.e. shock), then administration of vasopressors is appropriate.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of progressive abdominal distention, pain, nausea, and vomiting for 24 hours. His last bowel movement was 3 days ago. His past medical history includes a motor vehicle accident 2 years ago for which the patient required an exploratory laparotomy. Temperature is 36.8 ℃ (98.2 °F), pulse 98/min, respiratory rate 16/min, blood pressure 132/88, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. His abdominal X-ray images are displayed below. Which of the following abdominal examination findings would indicate the underlying cause of this patient’s condition?


Image source Openi
questions.solution:
This patient’s history and X-ray images (showing bowel dilation, air-fluid levels, and paucity of air in the rectum) are consistent with small bowel obstruction (SBO). Adhesions from previous abdominal surgeries are the most common cause of SBO (evidenced by surgical scars on the abdomen). Hernias are another common cause. SBO occurs when a blockage in the small bowel prevents the passage of intraluminal contents (e.g., gas, chyme), which results in distention of the bowel proximal to the obstruction. This condition manifests with pain, abdominal distention, nausea, and vomiting.

Adhesions are bands of scar-like tissue that can form between organs or between an organ and the abdominal wall. They often develop after abdominal surgery, particularly open surgery or emergency surgery. Less commonly, adhesions can develop from nonoperative trauma to the abdomen. Small bowel loops can twist around or become kinked by adhesions, resulting in SBO.

Since adhesions are the most common cause of SBO, it is important to elicit any surgical or traumatic history in patients with a suspected SBO. Other general findings in SBO include abdominal distention, tenderness, tympany to percussion, high-pitched and hyperactive bowel sounds early, and decreased bowel sound later in the course.
 

Option Analysis

❌ High-pitched bowel sounds:
Incorrect: High-pitched “tinkling” bowel sounds may be heard in early small bowel obstruction; however, this general finding does not suggest a specific diagnosis and cause of the obstruction.  
✅ Surgical scar:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abdominal distention:
Incorrect: Varying levels of abdominal distention may occur in small bowel obstruction; however, this finding does not point to a specific cause for the obstruction.  
❌ Tympany to percussion:
Incorrect: Tympany to percussion may occur with over-air-filled loops of bowel in small bowel obstruction; however, this finding does not point to a specific cause for the obstruction.  
❌ Hypoactive bowel sounds:
Incorrect: Hypoactive bowel sounds may occur in small bowel obstruction as the bowel becomes progressively distended; however, this finding does not point to a specific cause for the obstruction.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of abdominal pain, distention, obstipation, and vomiting. CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows dilated small bowel with a transition point, and decompressed colon and rectum. The patient is provided with IV fluids, electrolyte replacement, and has a nasogastric tube placed. He is admitted to the hospital for bowel rest and decompression. By day 5, his symptoms have improved, but attempts to discontinue bowel decompression and initiate oral intake result in a recurrence of pain, distention, and vomiting, and placement of a second NG tube. He has not had a bowel movement or passed flatus since admission. Temperature is 36.6 ℃ (97.9 ℉), pulse 77/min, respiratory rate 14/min, blood pressure 120/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. On examination, his abdomen appears distended, is tympanic to percussion, with hyperactive, high-pitched bowel sounds. There is no rebound or guarding. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is hospitalized with simple small bowel obstruction (SBO), as evidenced by abdominal distention, pain, vomiting, obstipation, and associated CT findings. As no concerning findings were found on CT that would require urgent surgical consultation (e.g., bowel ischemia, perforation, malignancy, closed-loop obstruction), he was appropriately treated with conservative measures. This includes nasogastric (NG) tube placement for bowel decompression, bowel rest, IV fluid hydration, and electrolyte replacement.

Additional measures should include serial abdominal examinations (and potential serial X-rays), as well as assessments of the patient’s symptoms and other signs of SBO resolution (e.g., flatus, bowel movements). With evidence of improvement, bowel decompression may be held, and a diet trial may be initiated.

When there is an inadequate response to conservative management after 3–5 days, surgical consultation is warranted and exploratory laparotomy may be needed. Additional factors that should prompt surgical consultation include signs of peritonitis, hemodynamic instability, signs of impending perforation, or imaging signs of bowel ischemia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Continue current care:
Incorrect: This patient’s small bowel obstruction has not responded to 5 days of conservative management. After this point, it is recommended to consult surgery.  
❌ Remove the nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: Since the patient’s symptoms worsen when bowel decompression is discontinued, removing the nasogastric tube would likely not improve his condition.  
❌ Administer metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Promotility agents, like metoclopramide, are contraindicated in small bowel obstruction.  
✅ Consult surgery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer oral magnesium citrate:
Incorrect: Laxatives, such as magnesium citrate, are contraindicated in small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for pyelonephritis and started on intravenous fluids, analgesics, and ceftriaxone. Over the next few days the patient develops worsening abdominal pain, distention, and nausea. The patient’s last bowel movement was prior to admission. Temperature is 37.2 °C (98.9 °F), pulse is 94/min, blood pressure is 111/78 mmHg, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has a distended abdomen, mild diffuse tenderness to palpation and no guarding or rebound tenderness. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates colonic dilatation without evidence of mechanical obstruction. Fluid hydration and electrolyte replacement are continued. A nasogastric tube is placed for bowel decompression and opioid pain medications are discontinued. Which of the following additional measures should be considered if the condition persists?

choices.text: Call surgical consultation for endoscopic decompression

questions.solution:
This patient’s history, examination, and imaging are consistent with a large bowel obstruction. The CT findings of colonic dilatation without evidence of a mechanical obstruction indicate colonic pseudo-obstruction, a functional (adynamic) form of large bowel obstruction. This is also called Ogilvie syndrome. Risk factors for this condition include advanced age, hospitalization with severe illness, trauma or surgery, electrolyte imbalances, and certain medications (e.g. opioids).
 

In stable patients without evidence of complicated disease (e.g., ischemia, perforation), supportive care is most appropriate. This includes fluid hydration, electrolyte replacement, bowel decompression via nasogastric tube if nausea and vomiting is present, and discontinuation of motility-inhibiting medications (e.g. opioids). Serial abdominal examinations and abdominal radiographs can help to monitor for signs of improvement or worsening. In patients who do not respond to initial therapy, a trial of a cholinesterase inhibitor (e.g. neostigmine) may stimulate bowel motility.

In patients who do not respond to supportive care and a cholinesterase inhibitor, or clinically worsen, surgical consultation for exploratory laparotomy is recommended. Additionally, immediate surgical consultation should be obtained for patients who develop hemodynamic instability, signs of peritonitis, or laboratory and imaging concerning for ischemia or perforation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administer erythromycin:
Incorrect: Erythromycin to stimulate bowel activity has not been found to be efficacious for colonic pseudo-obstruction. It is more appropriate for gastroparesis or sometimes prior to upper endoscopy in severe active gastric bleeding.  
✅ Administer neostigmine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Call surgical consultation for laparotomy:
Incorrect: Surgical consultation would be indicated for colonic pseudo-obstruction complicated by ischemia or perforation, or if the individual does not improve with supportive care and neostigmine. This patient is hemodynamically stable without peritoneal signs and has not had a full trial of supportive care and neostigmine.  
❌ Call surgical consultation for endoscopic decompression:
Incorrect: Endoscopic decompression can be considered in cases where neostigmine is ineffective or contraindicated. This patient does not have any contraindications for neostigmine so a trial of this medication would be appropriate first.  
❌ Administer atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that can be used as an antispasmodic agent due to its inhibition of GI motility. This would be contraindicated in colonic pseudo-obstruction.

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is on an inpatient medicine unit after undergoing surgery for a left hip fracture 5 days ago. Her postoperative pain has been difficult to manage, and she has required significant amounts of narcotic pain medication. The patient notes that she feels bloated and has not had a solid bowel movement since admission. She states she does not have much of an appetite but she has not had nausea or vomiting and can still pass flatus. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8), blood pressure is 123/77, pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, her abdomen is soft but distended, mildly tender to deep palpation, and without rebound tenderness or guarding. On digital rectal examination, a bulky and hard mass of stool is palpated in the rectum. Bedside abdominal X-ray confirms a large colonic stool burden. After performing a successful manual disimpaction, which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
Decrease in narcotic pain medication dosage and initiation of a bowel regimen

questions.solution:
This post-surgical patient with abdominal distention and the inability to pass a large mass of stool in the rectum, has a clinical diagnosis of fecal impaction. While fecal impaction is a clinical diagnosis based on signs, symptoms, and the presence of a hard mass of stool on digital rectal examination, an abdominal x-ray may be used to confirm the diagnosis and rule out perforation or other complications. Colonic feces appear heterogeneous with mixed soft tissue and gas densities. Once manual disimpaction is performed, this patient’s narcotic pain medications should be appropriately decreased to a dose that minimizes pain but does not lead to significant constipation, and a bowel regimen should be initiated.

Fecal impaction can occur when there is an anatomic or physiologic disruption in colonic transit leading to the inability to pass stool through peristalsis. Patients may have a history of advanced age, institutionalization or long-term care, hypothyroidism, neuropsychiatric diagnoses, or other medical or anatomical causes leading to difficult or decreased colonic transit. The underlying cause of fecal impaction, which in this patient is likely the use of narcotic medication for postoperative pain control, should be addressed.
 

The mainstays of treatment for fecal impaction include IV fluids, bowel rest and insertion of a nasogastric tube if the patient has abdominal distention and nausea or vomiting, electrolyte repletion, manual disimpaction, addressing the underlying causes of constipation and initiating a bowel regimen. After initiating therapy, the patient can be followed clinically with serial abdominal exams and monitoring for the return of regular bowel movements.

Option Analysis

❌ Nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: Nasogastric tube insertion for gastric decompression would be appropriate if the patient was having nausea, vomiting, or signs of functional or mechanical obstruction. However, this patient has not experienced nausea or vomiting and is still able to pass flatus.
❌ CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: This patient’s clinical history, lack of signs of peritonitis on abdominal examination, and the presence of a bulky mass of stool in the rectum are consistent with a clinical diagnosis of fecal impaction. While a CT scan can be helpful to assess for complications of fecal impaction, such as stercoral colitis or perforation, at this time CT imaging is not indicated.  
❌ Observation:
Incorrect: After performing manual disimpaction a bowel regimen should be initiated and the underlying  causes of fecal impaction should be addressed. Observation alone would not be sufficient.
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Utilizing endoscopy as a therapeutic intervention for fecal impaction would only be considered in refractory cases. In this case, the patient was able to undergo a successful manual disimpaction; therefore her opioid medications should be decreased as appropriate and a bowel regimen should be initiated.  
✅ Decrease in narcotic pain medication dosage and initiation of a bowel regimen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of abdominal distension. The patient has had abdominal pain, nausea, and decreased appetite associated with progressive abdominal distension for the past three days. His last bowel movement was five days ago. The rest of the review of systems is unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for chronic constipation, hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. The patient had an open cholecystectomy several years ago. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows a distended and tympanitic abdomen with diffuse tenderness to palpation, but no rigidity, rebound tenderness, or guarding. A supine abdominal x-ray is shown below. Which pathophysiological process most likely contributed to this patient’s condition?  



Reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Circumferential laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane
Twisting of the sigmoid colon about its mesentery
Intestinal obstruction due to paralytic ileus
Telescoping of the proximal intestine into distal intestine
Inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall

questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation is typical of intestinal obstruction (e.g., abdominal distention, abdominal pain, nausea, and constipation). This, together with a history of chronic constipation, is suggestive of sigmoid volvulus.   

Sigmoid volvulus occurs when an air-filled loop of the sigmoid colon twists about its mesentery, forming a closed-loop obstruction. The symptoms of volvulus are those of acute bowel obstruction. Patients present with progressive abdominal distention, nausea, and vomiting (secondary to continuous gas production by the intraluminal bacteria). This can rapidly progress to generalized abdominal pain and tenderness.    

Factors that can precipitate the development of sigmoid volvulus include: 
  •  Long redundant sigmoid colon with a narrow mesenteric attachment 
  •  Chronic constipation 
  •  Hirschsprung disease 
  •  Colonic hypomotility (e.g., neurogenic bowel in neurogenic diseases and diabetic enteropathy) 
  Sigmoid volvulus produces a characteristic bent inner tube or coffee bean appearance, with the convexity of the loop lying in the right upper quadrant (opposite the site of obstruction) on plain abdominal x-ray. The coffee bean appearance of the colon is created when the sigmoid colon distends with gas and the medial walls of the dilated bowel loop oppose one another and form the cleft of the coffee bean or an inverted U shape.  



Option Analysis

❌ Circumferential laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane:
Incorrect: Sliding hiatal hernias occur due to the laxity of the phrenoesophageal membrane leading to the herniation of the gastroesophageal junction and proximal stomach into the thoracic cavity. Patients usually present with reflux symptoms (e.g., heartburn, regurgitation, and chest pain). This patient’s presentation is suggestive of intestinal obstruction.  
✅ Twisting of the sigmoid colon about its mesentery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intestinal obstruction due to paralytic ileus:
Incorrect: Paralytic ileus results when there is a nonmechanical decrease in flow of intestinal contents. It can lead to intestinal obstruction which is seen on abdominal x-ray as generalized distension of small and large bowel. A coffee-bean sign as seen on this patient’s plain radiograph suggests sigmoid volvulus.  
❌ Telescoping of the proximal intestine into distal intestine:
Incorrect: Intussusception (telescoping of the proximal intestine into the distal intestine) can cause intermittent, colicky abdominal pain and currant jelly stools. It typically occurs in infants aged 6-36 months. Plain abdominal radiographs may show a “target sign”, not the coffee bean sign seen in this patient.  
❌ Inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall:
Incorrect: Diverticulitis (inflammation of the sac-like protrusion of the colonic wall) can present with left lower quadrant pain. It usually does not cause mechanical intestinal obstruction or a coffee bean sign on x-ray.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting for one day.  He has not had a bowel movement or passed gas for 24 hours. He has an incisional hernia at the site of a previous cholecystectomy. He states that the hernia typically reduces on its own, but he feels it has been “stuck” in place today. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and blood pressure is 162/88 mmHg. On exam, he is in significant distress due to the pain. Examination of the abdominal wall reveals a tender bulging mass in the right upper quadrant at the site of the scar. The overlying skin appears dusky with surrounding erythema. During the assessment, the patient has an episode of bilious emesis. A nasogastric tube is placed. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of oral ciprofloxacin and observation
Administration of IV piperacillin-tazobactam and observation

questions.solution:
This patient’s tender, bulging abdominal mass with overlying skin changes in the area of a prior surgical incision is indicative of a strangulated incisional hernia. Moreover, this patient has evidence of vomiting and lack of gas and stool passage indicating an acute bowel obstruction.  Emergent surgical consultation is indicated, along with broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, and IV fluids.

When a loop of bowel becomes trapped in an incisional hernia, blood supply to the bowel wall becomes compromised resulting in a strangulated hernia, which is a surgical emergency. Strangulated hernias are typically visible and palpable in the wall of the abdomen, and the overlying skin may appear dusky and erythematous. When clinical and physical exam findings suggest a strangulated hernia, caution should be taken during the abdominal exam, and manual reduction of the herniais contraindicated since the introduction of necrotic bowel into the abdominal cavity can lead to life-threatening abdominal sepsis. Symptoms of associated bowel obstruction including nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, and lack of flatus may be present.

A strangulated hernia is an emergent condition that requires prompt surgical consultation, as well as medical management and supportive care.  This includes stabilization of the patient, IV fluid resuscitation as needed, followed by initiation of broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, and placement of a nasogastric tube for decompression if an acute bowel obstruction is present.  

Option Analysis

✅ Emergent surgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Manual reduction of the hernia:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a strangulated hernia which may contain necrotic bowel tissue, therefore manual reduction is contraindicated since necrotic bowel contents can be released into the abdominal cavity.  
❌ CT of the abdomen/pelvis:
Incorrect: With clinical evidence of a strangulated hernia, surgery should be consulted immediately.  A CT of the abdomen and pelvis may be incorporated into the pre-surgical management, but should not delay the emergent consultation.  
❌ Administration of oral ciprofloxacin and observation:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of an acute bowel obstruction, and oral administration of medication is contraindicated. Broad-spectrum empiric IV antibiotics should be given in addition to calling an emergent surgery consultation.  
❌ Administration of IV piperacillin-tazobactam and observation:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a strangulated hernia. Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics are appropriate, but emergent surgical consultation is required for definitive treatment.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man on the surgical floor has new-onset abdominal discomfort and bloating 48 hours postoperatively following a right hemicolectomy. His surgery was uncomplicated. He has been unable to pass flatus and stool since the procedure. Heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 100/56 mmHg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and temperature is 37.2 °C (99.0 °F). On examination, bowel sounds are diminished. The abdomen is mildly tender, distended, and tympanic to percussion. A peripheral IV is placed with administration of IV fluids. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms (e.g., abdominal discomfort, bloating, inability to pass flatus and stool) and signs (e.g., abdominal distension, mild tenderness, tympany, decreased bowel sounds) of postoperative ileus following abdominal surgery.  When evaluating a postoperative patient with abdominal discomfort, it is important to examine the surgical wounds as wound infection, herniation, perforation and peritonitis could all be causes of abdominal pain in a patient after abdominal surgery.

Ileus refers to a functional obstruction of the intestines that may arise due to reduced or absent peristalsis without an underlying mechanical blockage. This is a common postoperative complication, particularly following abdominal surgeries. The condition is likely secondary to inflammation and a neurohumoral response to bowel manipulation. Nonsurgical causes of ileus include medications that slow peristalsis (e.g. opiates) and systemic conditions (e.g. sepsis).

When assessing a patient with suspected postoperative ileus, an ABCDE evaluation and stabilization of the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation takes priority. Vital sign monitoring, obtaining IV access, and starting IV fluid hydration are part of the management. Additionally, an examination of the surgical wounds should be performed to rule out other causes of abdominal pain or mechanical obstruction before obtaining additional diagnostic studies or starting therapeutic interventions for suspected ileus.  

Option Analysis

✅ Examine the surgical wounds:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtain an abdominal X-ray:
Incorrect: An abdominal X-ray can show dilated bowel loops suggestive of ileus, and should be done to help rule out mechanical obstruction; however, it is imperative to first check the surgical wounds of any post-operative patient with new-onset abdominal pain.  
❌ Start broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: This patient has likely developed a postoperative ileus. There is no indication for antibiotic therapy at this time.  
❌ Insert a nasogastric tube:
Incorrect: Nasogastric decompression can provide symptomatic relief for patients with ileus. However, while evaluating this post-operative patient, assessment of surgical wounds takes precedence.  
❌ Administer prokinetic agents:
Incorrect: Prokinetic agents can be useful for stimulating bowel motility. However, they're not the first step in addressing post-operative abdominal pain.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of worsening abdominal pain and distension over the past 3 days. He has not had a bowel movement over this period of time.  He had a severe lumbar sprain 2 weeks ago and was prescribed medications for pain control. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 82/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the abdomen is distended and tympanic to percussion with decreased bowel sounds on auscultation. The scout CT image is displayed below. Which of the following would be most consistent with the suspected diagnosis?
 

Image courtesy of Radiopaedia

choices.text: Positive Murphy's sign on abdominal examination

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms (e.g., abdominal pain, inability to pass stool) and signs (e.g., abdominal distention, tympany, decreased bowel sounds) of ileus in the setting of recent analgesia use. His X-ray demonstrates diffuse dilation of the intestines without a clear transition point, consistent with ileus. Recent use of opiate analgesics is most likely to have caused this condition.

Ileus refers to a functional obstruction of the intestines that may arise due to reduced or absent peristalsis without an underlying mechanical blockage. This is a common postoperative complication, particularly following abdominal surgeries. Non-postoperative causes of ileus include medications that slow peristalsis (e.g., opiates, anticholinergics), systemic conditions (e.g., metabolic abnormalities, sepsis), intra-abdominal pathology (e.g., diverticulitis, appendicitis), and radiation. For a nonsurgical ileus, the etiology can usually be elucidated by taking a careful patient history.

Patients presenting with ileus will often have signs and symptoms similar to small bowel obstruction. This can include abdominal pain, bloating, obstipation, nausea, and vomiting. Physical examination may demonstrate abdominal distention, tenderness to palpation, tympany to percussion, and diminished or absent bowel sounds. Abdominal imaging, such as an X-ray or CT, can help differentiate ileus from small bowel obstruction. Radiographic findings of ileus include small bowel dilation without evidence of a transition point.  

Option Analysis

✅ Use of opioid analgesics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recent traumatic abdominal injury:
Incorrect: Traumatic abdominal injury, such as blunt force trauma, can cause intra-abdominal adhesions and mechanical small bowel obstruction. This patient’s X-ray and likely opioid use are more consistent with ileus.  
❌ History of chronic constipation:
Incorrect: Chronic constipation can cause abdominal distension and discomfort, but it would not likely precipitate the acute presentation seen in this patient and findings of ileus on X-ray.  
❌ Positive Murphy's sign on abdominal examination:
Incorrect: A positive Murphy's sign (pain upon deep inspiration while the examiner's fingers are placed under the right costal margin) suggests acute cholecystitis or inflammation of the gallbladder and not ileus.  
❌ Heavy alcohol consumption:
Incorrect: A history of heavy alcohol consumption combined would not typically be associated with causing generalized abdominal distension, lack of bowel movements, and ileus.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman had an uneventful laparotomy for appendicitis 3 days ago. On postoperative day 3, she had abdominal bloating and vomiting. She has not passed flatus or had a bowel movement since her surgery. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, heart rate is 92 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On examination, the surgical wounds are clean and dry without significant erythema. The abdomen is distended, mildly tender to palpation without rebound or guarding and tympanic to percussion. Bowel sounds are infrequent. An abdominal X-ray shows dilated loops of small bowel without a transition point. She is started on IV hydration. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of postoperative ileus, which is consistent with her X-ray findings. The most appropriate next step is nasogastric tube decompression to help alleviate her bowel distention and symptoms.

Ileus refers to a functional obstruction of the intestines that may arise due to reduced or absent peristalsis without an underlying mechanical blockage. The most common cause is recent abdominal surgery. Monitoring a patient’s abdominal examination and ability to pass flatus and stool is critical in the postoperative period.

Management of postoperative ileus includes supportive care with bowel rest, nasogastric tube decompression, IV fluid hydration, and electrolyte monitoring/replacement. Patients are encouraged to ambulate and avoid medications that can inhibit peristalsis (e.g., opiates) Monitoring involves serial abdominal exams and abdominal X-rays to gauge response to therapy. Once improvement is seen, patients should have a trial of oral intake. If patients do not respond appropriately, develop signs of sepsis, or worsen clinically, a CT of the abdomen and pelvis should be ordered to look for complications.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nasogastric tube decompression:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Administering a prokinetic agent, such as metoclopramide, is not the first-line management for ileus. These medications can enhance gut motility, but their efficacy in treating postoperative ileus remains uncertain.  
❌ Parenteral nutrition:
Incorrect: Initiating parenteral nutrition is premature at this point. This therapy is reserved for patients who cannot tolerate enteral feeds or those with a contraindication to oral or enteral intake.  
❌ Exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: An exploratory laparotomy is an invasive procedure. It would not be the next step for treating a patient without evidence of a surgical complication or acute pathology causing the ileus.  
❌ Close monitoring:
Incorrect: Close monitoring without active intervention could potentially prolong the patient's discomfort and distention. Given the clinical picture, an intervention is necessary to relieve the patient's symptoms and promote bowel function recovery.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 10-hour history of abdominal pain and a five-day history of constipation. He reports prior episodes of constipation that resolved with increasing his fluid and fiber intake. He does not have hematochezia or unintentional weight loss. He has a history of hypercholesterolemia which is well-controlled with atorvastatin. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.1°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 123/82 mmHg. Abdominal examination reveals a distended tympanic abdomen with diffuse rebound tenderness with guarding and hyperactive bowel sounds. No obstructing masses are detected on the digital rectal exam. Based on this patient’s presentation and findings, colonic volvulus is strongly suspected. Which of the following findings would support a diagnosis of cecal volvulus as opposed to sigmoid volvulus?

choices.text: Single air-fluid level on abdominal x-ray

questions.solution:
In this patient presenting with abdominal pain and constipation and prior episodes of constipation, who is found to have a distended tender tympanic abdomen with hyperactive bowel sounds and rebound tenderness, colonic volvulus is suspected. Patients with cecal volvulus can have variable presentations from insidious abdominal pain to acute severe abdominal pain. In patients with a cecal volvulus, abdominal x-rays will typically show a single air-fluid level in the left upper quadrant. Additionally, a massively dilated cecum with small bowel dilation corresponding to bowel obstruction can be seen.

CT scan and contrast studies (barium or water-soluble) in both cecal and sigmoid volvulus can show the characteristic bird’s beak sign (seen in the image below). CT scan can also show a whirl sign in both sigmoid and cecal volvulus. Abdominal x-ray in combination with CT scan is typically used to make the diagnosis. A rare type of cecal volvulus where the cecum folds anteriorly instead of twisting around its axis (cecal bascule) can also occur and should be suspected if the cecum appears as a dilated loop of bowel in the center of the abdomen.

Once a diagnosis of cecal volvulus is made, urgent surgical consultation for a right hemicolectomy is necessary, as detorsion alone without hemicolectomy is associated with a failure rate of up to 75%. Stable patients can have the segment detorsed at the time of surgery prior to resection.
 

 Image courtesy of StatDX
Frontal radiograph after a water-soluble contrast enema shows narrowing of the ascending colon, which ends proximally in a twist, leading to upstream dilation in this cecal volvulus.  

Option Analysis

✅ Single air-fluid level on abdominal x-ray:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Whirl sign on CT scan:
Incorrect: A whirl sign on CT scan can be seen in both cecal and sigmoid volvulus and results from twisting of the colon and the mesentery along the axis of the volvulus.  
❌ Leukocytosis:
Incorrect: An elevated white blood cell count can be seen with both cecal and sigmoid volvulus.  
❌ Metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: Metabolic acidosis can be seen in both cecal and sigmoid volvulus due to elevated lactate levels.  
❌ Pneumoperitoneum:
Incorrect: Pneumoperitoneum, or air under the diaphragm, is an ominous finding that indicates bowel perforation, which is a surgical emergency. Pneumoperitoneum can be a complication of both cecal and sigmoid volvulus.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for vomiting and fussiness. Two hours prior to presentation, the patient had an episode of vomiting, non-bloody, non-bilious emesis, and developed subsequent abdominal distension. He began crying and has been inconsolable, which is uncharacteristic for him. The parent states that the patient is otherwise healthy, up-to-date on vaccinations, and meeting developmental milestones. In the emergency department, temperature by rectum is 38°C (100.4°F), heart rate is 180/min, respiratory rate is 50/min and labored, blood pressure is 82/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. Physical exam is notable for an ill-appearing child. Bowel sounds are high-pitched. The abdomen is distended, tense, and tender to palpation in the right lower quadrant. There is a firm, tender mass in the right groin that is non-reducible with overlying erythema. Both testicles are palpable in the scrotum. Lab work is obtained and pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Incision and drainage of the right groin mass
Manual reduction of the groin mass

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department for evaluation of vomiting, inconsolable crying, and abdominal distension. On exam, the patient has findings consistent with a small bowel obstruction, incarcerated right inguinal hernia, and acute abdomen. Vital signs show tachypnea and hypoxia, placing the patient at risk for respiratory failure. Before further management, this patient requires stabilization of airway, breathing, and circulation. This patient who is hypoxic on room air should receive supplemental O2.

When a pediatric patient presents with findings suggestive of an acute abdomen, the first step in management is to perform an ABCDE assessment to determine if the patient is stable or unstable. Most patients with an acute abdomen are unstable, and airway, breathing, and circulation should be stabilized. Patients should have IV access established, IV fluid resuscitation with continuous monitoring of vital signs, and supplemental oxygen if necessary. Additionally, the patient should be made NPO (Nil Per Os) in anticipation of surgical intervention and a nasogastric tube may be placed for decompression. 

Manual reduction of an incarcerated hernia may be attempted at the bedside in patients who are stable and without signs of strangulation or acute abdomen. However, this patient should go directly for surgical repair once he is stabilized.   

Option Analysis

❌ Incision and drainage of the right groin mass  :
Incorrect: This patient presents with findings consistent with an acute abdomen secondary to small bowel obstruction from an incarcerated right inguinal hernia. The patient is tachypneic and unstable. Before definitive management, this patient requires stabilization. If this patient had an abscess, incision, and drainage would be the treatment of choice. However, the mass is firm and not fluctuant and boggy, which would be expected with an abscess.  
❌ Manual reduction of the groin mass :
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of an Incarcerated right inguinal hernia. In this patient who appears ill, with acute abdomen and signs of obstruction, manual reduction should not be attempted. Airways and breathing should be stabilized.  
✅ Supplemental oxygen :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Emergency surgical consultation  :
Incorrect: This patient presents with an acute abdomen and incarcerated right inguinal hernia. Unstable patients with an acute abdomen require ABCDE assessment with stabilization before any intervention including calling a consultation.  
❌ Outpatient ultrasonography  :
Incorrect: In a child with an inguinal hernia, especially those under two years of age and in unstable patients, urgent or emergency surgery is indicated. This patient should be stabilized and then go for surgery.

questions.text: An undomiciled adult man is found unconscious and brought to the emergency department by emergency services. Initial vital signs reveal a heart rate of 125 /min and a blood pressure of 77/45 mm Hg. Intravenous (IV) access is obtained, and a bolus of crystalloid fluid is started. Repeat blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg. The patient is confused and unable to answer questions appropriately. Physical exam shows mucosal pallor, capillary refill > 3 seconds, and several surgical scars on the abdomen with an ileostomy without signs of infection. A foley catheter is inserted and drains 40 cc of dark yellow urine. A total body CT (Computed Tomography) scan reveals evidence of small bowel surgery. Which of the following would be a risk factor for short bowel syndrome in this patient?

choices.text: Prior resection of 75 cm of the small intestine with the terminal ileum intact
Prior resection with 180 cm of small bowel remaining

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of severe dehydration, abdominal scars and an ileostomy, and an unclear medical and surgical history. A CT scan reveals evidence of bowel surgery, and short bowel syndrome is the most likely diagnosis. Prior small bowel resection that left only 180 cm of small bowel remaining would be a risk factor for the development of short bowel syndrome in this patient.       

For adults, an anatomic definition of short bowel syndrome is a residual small bowel length < 200 cm, measured from the duodenojejunal flexure, with or without colon. The term "functional short bowel syndrome" is sometimes used to describe patients with a residual small bowel length > 200 cm but with impaired function due to factors such as the presence of underlying disease (e.g. Crohn disease), colon resection, or other causes of rapid intestinal transit. Insufficient bowel length or function results in malabsorption of water, electrolytes, and nutrients.       

Patients with short bowel syndrome can present with severe diarrhea or high stoma output if they have one. A high stoma output is defined as > 1.2 L per day. Additionally, they may have significant weight loss, decreased or absent urine output, lethargy, weakness, or altered mental status. Physical examination may reveal evidence of volume depletion, such as tachycardia, hypotension, dry mucous membranes, and decreased skin turgor.   

Option Analysis

❌ History of irritable bowel syndrome :
Incorrect: A history of irritable bowel syndrome and prior small bowel surgery would not be a risk factor for short bowel syndrome. However, a history of bowel resection and inflammatory bowel disease (i.e., Crohn disease, ulcerative colitis) would be a potential risk factor. 
❌ Prior resection of 75 cm of the small intestine with the terminal ileum intact :
Incorrect: Typical estimates of small bowel length in adults vary from 300-800 cm. The risk for short bowel syndrome increases when < 200 cm of small bowel remains after resection. Removal of 75 cm of small intestine would not be enough to reach this threshold. Additionally, since the terminal ileum is important for the absorption of nutrients, bile, and fluid, leaving it intact would help prevent short bowel syndrome. 
❌ Recent sphincteroplasty for Crohn disease :
Incorrect: There are several distinct types of sphincteroplasty, but all of them preserve the intestine. Even though there is likely malabsorption at the site of the sphincteroplasty, that alone without removal of the intestine is not enough to cause short bowel syndrome. 
❌ Consistent Ileostomy output <1200 mL  :
Incorrect: Patients with ileostomies need to be mindful of their daily output, as they can become dehydrated quickly. If the output is consistently greater than 1200-1300 mL per day and the patient is unable to decrease the output with antimotility agents, they will likely have short bowel syndrome. 
✅ Prior resection with 180 cm of small bowel remaining :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents for evaluation of bloody bowel movements. Over the past five months, the patient has had recurrent episodes of bright red blood covering her stool and associated perianal itching. She has not experienced unintentional weight loss, decreased appetite, pain with defecation, or a change in stool caliber. The patient works as a truck driver, and her diet consists mainly of fast food. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg, and pulse is 90/min. The external anorectal examination is unremarkable. Endoscopy reveals the following findings at the anorectal junction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with painless hematochezia and perianal pruritus with a history of a low-fiber diet and prolonged sitting. Endoscopic examination reveals multiple purplish-red swollen lumps at the anorectal junction. Together, these findings are consistent with internal hemorrhoids.   

Hemorrhoids refer to varicose veins at the anorectum that form secondary to persistently elevated venous pressure in the hemorrhoidal plexus. Risk factors include prolonged or excessive straining, constipation, and increased age.  

Hemorrhoids can be classified as external (distal to the dentate line), internal (proximal to the dentate line), or combined (found on both sides of the dentate line).  

Patients with external hemorrhoids typically present with a history of a palpable external lump, anal pruritis, and perianal pain. Bleeding from external hemorrhoids is not typical. External hemorrhoids can be diagnosed with a digital rectal examination and may appear as tender, soft, swollen, or red lumps. Patients may develop non-tender skin tags from previous episodes of inflammation and thrombosis. In contrast patients with internal hemorrhoids present with painless bleeding with defecation and anal pruritis. Patients with internal hemorrhoids may present with prolapse of hemorrhoids out through the anus or they may not have any visible or palpable lumps. Anoscopy is typically required for the diagnosis of internal hemorrhoids.   

Option Analysis

❌ Colorectal cancer  :
Incorrect: Colorectal cancer can cause hematochezia, melena, unintentional weight loss, and changes in bowel habits (if the cancer is causing significant luminal narrowing). Colorectal cancer typically presents as a friable mass rather than multiple purplish-red swollen lumps.  
❌ Inflammatory bowel disease  :
Incorrect: This patient presents with multiple purplish-red swollen lumps in the anorectal region that are consistent with hemorrhoids. Inflammatory bowel disease presents with mucosal friability, erosion, and ulceration.   
❌ Perianal abscess:
Incorrect: Perianal abscesses are painful. This patient presents with painless hematochezia and perianal pruritus in the setting of multiple purplish-red swollen lumps identified on endoscopic examination. These findings are consistent with internal hemorrhoids.  
✅ Internal hemorrhoids  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Condyloma acuminatum  :
Incorrect: Condyloma acuminatum (also termed anogenital warts) is a skin infection that presents with cauliflower-like lesions over the genitalia and anus.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, nausea, and anorexia for the past day. The pain was initially felt around the patient’s belly button but is now primarily localized over the right lower abdomen. He has no significant medical history and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 37.4ºC (99.3ºF), pulse is 110/min, blood pressure is 101/73 mmHg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation over the right lower abdominal quadrant but is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory results show leukocytosis and an elevated CRP. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen pelvis with intravenous contrast

questions.solution:
This hemodynamically stable patient has symptoms that are concerning for acute appendicitis, including migratory right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and anorexia. Patients with suspected appendicitis should receive antiemetic therapy and analgesia for symptomatic management while a workup is performed to obtain a definitive diagnosis.

The first step in the acute management of appendicitis involves recognizing the unstable patient. Unstable patients with appendicitis typically develop sepsis and bowel perforation findings and appear ill with evidence of hemodynamic compromise. The first step in management of these unstable patients consists of stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. Healthcare providers may need to intubate the patient, establish IV access, or administer fluids.

If the patient is stable, the next step is obtaining a focused history and physical examination, specifically noting any examination findings such as the Rovsing or psoas signs. Laboratory testing often demonstrates non-specific findings, including an elevated white blood cell count and elevated inflammatory markers (e.g., C-reactive protein, erythrocyte sedimentation rate). Analgesics such as morphine and antiemetics such as ondansetron should be administered for pain and nausea control.

A definitive diagnosis of acute appendicitis can be made via a CT of the abdomen and pelvis or in certain cases via ultrasound or MRI.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of morphine and ondansetron:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Surgical consultation:
Incorrect: This patient has abdominal pain, nausea, and anorexia, but no definitive diagnosis has been made. Surgical consultation should be withheld until a definitive diagnosis is reached.  
❌ CT of the abdomen pelvis with intravenous contrast:
Incorrect: A CT of the abdomen pelvis with intravenous contrast is indicated to diagnose acute appendicitis definitively. However, treatment of this patient's symptoms should take precedence.  
❌ Administration of piperacillin-tazobactam:
Incorrect: Administration of antibiotics should be withheld until a definitive diagnosis of acute appendicitis is obtained.  
❌ Oral fluid challenge:
Incorrect: Patients with a suspected acute abdomen (e.g. appendicitis, pancreatitis, diverticulitis, cholecystitis) should only eat or drink (NPO) after surgical pathology has been definitively excluded in case they need to go to surgery. This patient presents with suspected appendicitis and should be kept NPO until imaging results are obtained.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with a 5-week history of severe, sharp anal pain with defecation. The patient reports recurrent episodes of bright red blood on the toilet paper after wiping. She has not experienced diarrhea, decreased appetite, weight loss, or change in stool caliber. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, and irritable bowel syndrome. Family history is significant for a sibling with Crohn disease. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 137/75 mmHg, and pulse is 74/min. Physical examination is remarkable for a tender superficial linear ulceration over the right lateral edge of the anal canal. Which of the following findings is most suggestive of the need for further studies in this patient?

choices.text: Lateral location of the linear ulceration

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 5-week history of severe anal pain related to defecation and hematochezia and a tender superficial linear ulceration on the right lateral edge of the anal canal. These findings are consistent with the diagnosis of an atypical anal fissure.

Anal fissures are longitudinal tears in the skin below the dentate line, a region innervated by somatic nerves. They can be divided into typical and atypical fissures. Typical anal fissures are usually caused by local trauma from constipation, straining during defecation, vaginal delivery, prolonged diarrhea, or anal intercourse. Patients with typical fissures present with a history of severe anal pain during and after defecation that can persist for minutes to hours, along with hematochezia. Physical examination typically reveals a tender superficial linear ulceration located in the midline of the anal canal, either posteriorly (which is the most common location), anteriorly, or at both locations.

Atypical anal fissures are caused by an underlying secondary etiology such as Crohn disease and other granulomatous diseases (e.g., tuberculosis, sarcoidosis), malignancy, or communicable diseases (e.g., HIV infection, syphilis). A patient with an atypical anal fissure may also report the presence of chronic multiple recurring non-healing fissures, and symptoms associated with the secondary underlying etiology. On physical examination, deep and wide fissures, painless fissures, fissures located in areas other than the midline, and findings related to an underlying secondary etiology (e.g., perianal skin tags in Crohn disease) may all indicate the presence of an atypical fissure. These patients require further evaluation to evaluate for an underlying secondary cause.

Further evaluation consists of endoscopic evaluation with a sigmoidoscopy or a colonoscopy. Colonoscopy is recommended for patients who have risk factors for colon cancer (e.g., age > 50 years old, family history of colon cancer). All other patients can undergo a sigmoidoscopy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lateral location of the linear ulceration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Age > 50 years:
Incorrect: Although anal fissures mostly present in the pediatric and middle-aged populations, they can occur in any age group.  
❌ Severe pain:
Incorrect: Severe pain that lasts for minutes to hours after defecation is a common symptom of anal fissure and is not an indication for further assessment.  
❌ Hematochezia:
Incorrect: Hematochezia, characterized by the presence of bright red blood on the toilet paper after wiping or on the stool surface, is a common symptom of both typical and atypical anal fissures, and by itself is not an indication of the need for further studies.  
❌ 5-week duration of symptoms:
Incorrect: The duration of symptoms is an important factor when assessing the chronicity of the condition and the management approach, however it does not indicate a need for further studies.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for 6 hours of severe generalized abdominal pain and subjective fever. The patient reports a 2-day history of constipation and left lower quadrant abdominal pain that has been increasing in severity. One year ago, he had an episode of constipation and left lower quadrant abdominal pain that was treated with oral antibiotics. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. BMI is 34 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 38.7 °C (102.6 °F), blood pressure is 90/52 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and room air oxygen saturation is 97%. Abdominal examination is significant for absent bowel sounds and severe diffuse tenderness with rigidity and guarding. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis and elevated C-reactive protein and lactate levels. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Administer IV fluids and refer for urgent surgical consultation
Obtain a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with oral and IV contrast
Administer oral antibiotics and discharge home with a follow-up appointment in 2-3 days
Administer IV antibiotics and admit to the hospital for observation

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a six-hour history of fever and severe generalized abdominal pain associated with guarding and rigidity. The patient is hypotensive with an elevated lactate level. In combination, these findings are concerning for peritonitis and septic shock. Given the patient’s preceding two-day history of LLQ abdominal pain and constipation, the most likely diagnosis is acute diverticulitis complicated by frank perforation and subsequent peritonitis, which is a surgical emergency.
 

Acute diverticulitis is characterized by inflammation of a diverticulum, a small pouch protruding from the bowel wall, most commonly occurring in the sigmoid colon in Western societies. Acute diverticulitis can be classified as uncomplicated diverticulitis, which usually presents with LLQ abdominal pain, alteration in bowel habits, and possibly fever. In contrast,  complicated diverticulitis is acute diverticulitis complicated by abscess, perforation, obstruction, or fistula.

In acute diverticulitis complicated by frank perforation, the patient may develop subsequent peritonitis, a surgical emergency that may lead to hemodynamic instability and septic shock. Based on the severity of the perforation, emergent surgery may be necessary. The most appropriate initial step in managing a hemodynamically unstable patient with suspected acute diverticulitis with frank perforation and peritonitis is stabilization with IV fluids and obtaining an urgent/emergent surgical consultation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV fluids and refer for urgent surgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtain a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with oral and IV contrast:
Incorrect: A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast would be appropriate for a hemodynamically stable patient with signs and symptoms of acute abdominal pathology. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of peritonitis and requires urgent stabilization before evaluation with CT scan.  
❌ Administer oral antibiotics and discharge home with a follow-up appointment in 2-3 days:
Incorrect: Oral antibiotics with follow-up appointment would be appropriate for a patient with confirmed uncomplicated acute diverticulitis who is hemodynamically stable and has high-risk features necessitating oral antibiotics (e.g., older than 70, immunosuppression, presence of multiple comorbidities). However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of peritonitis and requires urgent stabilization and a surgical consult.  
❌ Obtain an abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: If abdominal CT is unavailable or contraindicated, abdominal ultrasound can be performed to diagnose acute diverticulitis in a hemodynamically stable patient. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of peritonitis and requires urgent stabilization before further diagnostic evaluation.  
❌ Administer IV antibiotics and admit to the hospital for observation:
Incorrect: Although administering IV antibiotics is an important part of managing complicated acute diverticulitis, admitting the patient to the hospital for observation would be inappropriate as the patient is hemodynamically unstable with signs of peritonitis and requires urgent stabilization and surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of worsening lower abdominal pain, nausea, and fever reaching 38.9°C (102.0°F). The patient has had two episodes of diverticulitis in the past two years, which were treated with oral antibiotics. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 39.0 °C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 20/min. There is localized tenderness to palpation over the left lower quadrant. Serum white blood cell count is elevated. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with IV and oral contrast shows a 2.2-centimeter abscess around the sigmoid colon and multiple colonic inflamed diverticula with localized bowel wall thickening and pericolonic fat stranding. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital for bowel rest, IV antibiotics, and supportive care
Discharge on oral antibiotics, pain medications, clear liquid diet, and schedule a follow-up with outpatient surgery clinic in three days
Perform CT-guided percutaneous drainage of the abscess and initiate IV antibiotics
Discharge on pain medications, clear liquid diet, and schedule a follow-up with outpatient surgery clinic after three days

questions.solution:
For most cases of uncomplicated diverticulitis, management is non-surgical, and patients can be treated as outpatients. Treatment includes pain management, bowel rest with a clear liquid diet, and follow-up evaluation two to three days after presentation. Oral antibiotics targeting gram-negative rods and anaerobes are indicated in high-risk patients (age 70+, pregnancy, comorbidities such as heart disease, diabetes mellitus, or immunosuppression). Frequently a beta-lactam or fluoroquinolone is given with metronidazole. If the patient does not respond to outpatient treatment, hospitalization for intravenous antibiotics is indicated.

For complicated diverticulitis, the management is specific to the type of complication. All patients with complicated diverticulitis should be admitted to the hospital and started on IV hydration and IV antibiotics. Bowel rest is indicated initially.

The management of acute diverticulitis complicated by an abscess depends on the size of the abscess. An abscess that is 3 centimeters or less can be treated with IV antibiotics alone. Abscesses larger than 3 centimeters require percutaneous drainage in addition to IV antibiotics. A colectomy may be necessary if the patient does not clinically improve.
   

Acute diverticulitis complicated by frank perforation requires emergent laparotomy. Acute diverticulitis complicated by fistula formation may require surgery or prolonged bowel rest. Most patients with diverticulitis should have a follow-up colonoscopy six to eight weeks after the onset of acute diverticulitis to rule out any underlying malignancy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Admit to the hospital for bowel rest, IV antibiotics, and supportive care:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discharge on oral antibiotics, pain medications, clear liquid diet, and schedule a follow-up with outpatient surgery clinic in three days:
Incorrect: Oral antibiotics are indicated in uncomplicated acute diverticulitis in high-risk patients (age 70+, pregnancy, comorbidities such as heart disease, diabetes mellitus, immunosuppression). Given the findings of acute diverticulitis complicated by an abscess on a CT scan, this patient requires hospitalization and IV antibiotics.  
❌ Perform CT-guided percutaneous drainage of the abscess and initiate IV antibiotics:
Incorrect: Although IV antibiotics are indicated for this patient, CT-guided percutaneous drainage is not indicated for treating acute diverticulitis complicated by an abscess that is 3 cm or less in size.  
❌ Schedule an urgent partial colectomy:
Incorrect: An urgent partial colectomy is indicated for managing acute diverticulitis complicated by frank perforation, diffuse peritonitis, and acute diverticulitis that fails non-operative treatment. It would be inappropriate to recommend this treatment before other more conservative strategies are tried.  
❌ Discharge on pain medications, clear liquid diet, and schedule a follow-up with outpatient surgery clinic after three days:
Incorrect: Given the findings of acute diverticulitis complicated by an abscess on a CT scan, it would be inappropriate to discharge the patient from the hospital. This patient needs IV antibiotics.

A 72-year-old man is evaluated on the floors for abdominal pain two days after admission to the hospital. The patient reports moderately intense crampy abdominal pain in the left lower quadrant, and several episodes of bloody diarrhea and tenesmus. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 187/103 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical examination shows minimal diffuse abdominal tenderness that appears disproportionate to the patient’s symptom of moderate intensity crampy abdominal pain. The patient's laboratory findings are detailed below. Which of the following additional clinical or historical elements is most likely to be found?
 
Laboratory value   
Result
