Abdominal examination reveals a palpable "sausage-shaped" mass in the right mid-abdominal area that is tender to palpation. There is no rebound tenderness. Laboratory studies and imaging are pending. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of crampy abdominal pain, nausea, and bloody stools, along with examination findings of a palpable tender “sausage-shaped” mass in the right mid-abdominal area, are consistent with a diagnosis of intussusception.        

Patients with intussusception are typically infants and toddlers who present with sudden onset intermittent, severe, crampy, abdominal pain. They may exhibit inconsolable crying and drawing up of the knees toward the abdomen (to relieve pain). Vomiting (either bilious or non-bilious) can be a prominent symptom, often starting shortly after the first episodes of abdominal pain. Stool is grossly bloody in up to 50 percent of cases. “Currant jelly” stools can be observed which contain a combination of mucous and blood. Abdominal examination may show no tenderness or point tenderness in the mid or lower right abdomen. A “sausage-shaped” abdominal mass may be palpated on the right side of the abdomen.        

The majority of cases of intussusception are idiopathic, although an increasing body of evidence suggests that viral triggers may play a role in some cases. Viral illnesses can stimulate the growth of Peyer’s patches in the terminal ileum which may create lead points for ileo-colic intussusception. This patient recently recovered from an upper respiratory infection which was likely the trigger for intussusception.    

Option Analysis

❌ Appendicitis :
Incorrect: Appendicitis can present with crampy abdominal pain associated with nausea and vomiting; however, it usually presents with fever and right lower quadrant pain and tenderness. This patient’s presentation and examination findings including the sausage-shaped mass are consistent with intussusception.  
❌ Ovarian torsion :
Incorrect: Although ovarian torsion is typically associated with acute, crampy abdominal pain, it is not associated with bloody stools. Additionally, while ovarian torsion can occur at any age, it typically happens in women of childbearing age.  
✅ Intussusception :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Toxic ingestion :
Incorrect: Toxic ingestion should always be in the differential diagnosis for children presenting with vague, crampy abdominal pain. There should be a review conducted of all the prescribed medications and over-the-counter medications in the home. 
❌ Gastroenteritis  :
Incorrect: Gastroenteritis is a common etiology for children presenting with abdominal pain. Typically, patients with gastroenteritis present with vomiting, diarrhea, and/or fever; all of which are absent in this patient. The bloody stool and palpable sausage-shaped mass are consistent with intussusception.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presents to the emergency department accompanied by her parent for evaluation of fever and abdominal pain for two days. Her parent states that two days ago, she began complaining of vague abdominal pain. Today the pain worsened and migrated to the lower right quadrant. She also began experiencing fever, chills, nausea, and vomiting. She had three episodes of watery diarrhea and has a decreased appetite. She recently arrived back from a family vacation to Mexico, but the rest of her family remains healthy. Approximately 18 months ago, she had a right ovarian torsion that required surgical management. Temperature is 38°C (101.3°F), heart rate is 90/min, respiratory rate is 20 per minute, blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is uncomfortable and in pain. Abdominal exam is notable for tenderness over the right lower abdomen with rebound and guarding. Which of the following findings on ultrasound would be consistent with the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Enlarged right ovary with diminished or absent doppler flow
Spiral appearance of the duodenum and jejunum

questions.solution:
This eight-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and migratory right lower quadrant abdominal pain. She has evidence of an acute abdomen on exam with tenderness over McBurney’s point. Given these findings, acute appendicitis is the most likely diagnosis. Ultrasound is the diagnostic modality of choice for appendicitis in children given the lack of radiation. Ultrasound findings that support a diagnosis of appendicitis include a noncompressible tubular structure in the right lower quadrant, wall thickness greater than 2 mm, and diameter greater than 6 mm. These findings indicate a thickened and enlarged appendix.

Many conditions can cause acute abdomen in pediatric patients. The most likely causes differ based on age. In infants, intestinal malrotation and intussusception should be suspected. In older pediatric patients, gonadal torsion and appendicitis are more likely. Careful history and physical examination may not lead to a specific diagnosis and diagnostic imaging is typically necessary. 

In children, non-invasive and non-radiation-based imaging modalities are preferred. Ultrasound is typically the first-choice imaging modality. CT (Computed Tomography) imaging may be considered in some cases.    

Option Analysis

❌ Colonic inflammation with large, watery stool burden :
Incorrect: Patients with viral gastroenteritis or enterocolitis may have findings of intestinal/colonic inflammation or large watery stool burden on ultrasound. While this patient recently traveled to Mexico, none of her family members are sick and gastroenteritis would not typically present with acute abdomen. This patient with migratory abdominal pain and acute abdomen with tenderness, rebound, and guarding in the right lower quadrant likely has acute appendicitis. 
❌ Enlarged right ovary with diminished or absent doppler flow :
Incorrect: These are classic ultrasound findings seen with ovarian torsion. This patient has a history of right ovarian torsion, and recurrent torsion is possible, but diarrhea and migratory abdominal pain are not usually seen with ovarian torsions. Additionally, recurrent torsion on the same side as the repair would be unlikely. This patient with migratory abdominal pain and an acute abdomen with tenderness, rebound, and guarding in the right lower quadrant likely has acute appendicitis. 
✅ Thickened and enlarged appendix  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Spiral appearance of the duodenum and jejunum :
Incorrect: These findings are known as the “corkscrew” sign and can be seen with intestinal malrotation. Patients with intestinal malrotation typically present in the first two years of life with bright red blood per rectum and bilious vomiting. This 8-year-old patient with migratory abdominal pain and an acute abdomen with tenderness, rebound, and guarding in the right lower quadrant likely has acute appendicitis. 
❌ Target sign :
Incorrect: A target sign on ultrasound is often associated with intussusception, which typically presents in patients between the ages of 6 and 36 months. Patients typically present with lethargy, irritability, colicky abdominal pain, and “red currant jelly.” stool. This 8-year-old patient with migratory abdominal pain and an acute abdomen with tenderness, rebound, and guarding in the right lower quadrant likely has acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with diarrhea. He has a history of Crohn disease, for which he underwent small bowel resection 3 weeks ago due to complications from strictures. He is unsure as to the extent of the resection, but states, “It was a lot.” Since his discharge, he has lost 10 pounds and has experienced 3-5 episodes of diarrhea each day. This past week, he began feeling lethargic. He has not had any urine output in the past 36 hours, which prompted him to present for evaluation. Vitals are notable for a temperature of 37 ℃ (98.6℉), heart rate of 112 /min, blood pressure of 85/50 mm Hg, and respiratory rate of 20 /min. Physical examination is notable for dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Labs are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and admission to the hospital for monitoring

questions.solution:
Given this patient’s history of extensive bowel surgery and current clinical presentation, he likely has short bowel syndrome. He is tachycardic and hypotensive, indicating hemodynamic instability, and he has signs of volume depletion (e.g., reduced urine output, dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor). Thus, the best next step in management is to obtain IV access and provide crystalloid fluid resuscitation.       

Short bowel syndrome is characterized by insufficient length or function of the small intestines, resulting in malabsorption of water and electrolytes. The physiologic course of short bowel syndrome is characterized by two phases, the acute and adaptation phases. This patient is in the acute phase, which starts immediately after resection and lasts 3-4 weeks.        

The first step in management is to determine the stability of the patient. The predominant goals of management are to stabilize large fluid and electrolyte losses and maintain fluid and acid/base balance. Once that is achieved, acid suppression can be provided, followed by a thorough nutrition assessment. Typically, a combination of enteral and parenteral nutrition is recommended. Establishing contact with the patient’s operating surgeon is also imperative during the patient’s hospital course.    

Option Analysis

❌ Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and admission to the hospital for monitoring :
Incorrect: This patient is hypotensive and tachycardic, secondary to volume depletion from short bowel syndrome. Prior to initiating TPN, this patient should have a full assessment and be stabilized with intravenous fluid resuscitation.  
❌ Enteral access and nutrition  :
Incorrect: Enteral access is a vital component of managing the acute phase of short bowel syndrome. A combination of both enteral and parenteral nutrition is usually required to re-establish adequate nutrition. However, this patient is unstable and first requires resuscitation. 
✅ Intravenous (IV) access and crystalloid resuscitation :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Consultation with the operating surgeon :
Incorrect: The operating surgeon should be contacted regarding the care of their patient, but fluid resuscitation is the priority at this time.  
❌ Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy :
Incorrect: A PPI can be used in the acute phase of short bowel syndrome to suppress gastric hypersecretion and reduce fluid losses. However, prior to this, the patient needs to be stabilized with IV fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents to the emergency department (ED) with diarrhea. She has a history of Crohn disease complicated by strictures, for which she underwent an extensive small bowel resection two weeks ago. Since her discharge, she has experienced persistent diarrhea, which has recently increased in volume. Today, she began feeling weak, prompting her visit to the ED. On review of systems, she reports no fevers or chills, but she has lost 7 lb. in the past two weeks. She has not had any other surgeries. Temperature is 37 ℃ (98.6 ℉), heart rate is 84 /min, blood pressure is 110/76, and respiratory rate is 20 /min. On examination, she appears distressed, and her abdomen is mildly distended with recent surgical scars and a stoma without signs of infection. A rectal exam reveals no blood or masses. Laboratory studies are pending. Which of the following lab values would be consistent with the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given this patient’s presentation of diarrhea following recent, extensive bowel resection, she is at substantial risk of developing short bowel syndrome. The primary clinical concern in short bowel syndrome is significant malabsorption due to the reduced absorptive surface area of the intestine. An elevated fecal fat level would indicate malabsorption of fat and would be consistent with this syndrome.       

Initial evaluation of patients with likely short bowel syndrome aims to confirm malabsorption, assess its breadth (selective or global), and identify the underlying cause. The etiology of this patient’s short bowel syndrome can be elicited from history, but it should be confirmed by reviewing the operative reports to determine the length of the small bowel resected. If this information is unavailable, high-resolution computed tomography (CT) imaging can provide a detailed assessment of the patient’s anatomy. Laboratory tests might reveal microcytic anemia from iron deficiency or macrocytic anemia due to folate or vitamin B12 deficiency. There are also often electrolyte abnormalities, including hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and hypomagnesemia. Additionally, fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K) will likely be low. Fecal fat analysis is a practical initial test for assessing fat malabsorption. It is cost-effective and simple for both patients and laboratories to perform. In cases like this, where extensive bowel resection has occurred, an elevated fecal fat count is indicative of significant fat malabsorption, consistent with the diagnosis of short bowel syndrome.   

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated serum prealbumin :
Incorrect: Prealbumin is a measure of a patient’s nutritional status over the last several days. This patient likely has short bowel syndrome and would be expected to have poor nutritional status with a low prealbumin.  
❌ Normal serum vitamin D :
Incorrect: Patients with short bowel syndrome have malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins. These include vitamins A, D, E, and K. A low vitamin D level would be expected in this case. 
✅ Elevated fecal fat :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated serum potassium :
Incorrect: Patients with malabsorption usually experience hypokalemia due to the loss of potassium-rich fluid from the colon. 
❌ Elevated serum phosphate :
Incorrect: Hypophosphatemia, rather than hyperphosphatemia, is expected in patients with malabsorption syndromes, such as short bowel syndrome.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy presents with his parents to the pediatrician for evaluation of dark-colored stools for the past two weeks. The patient has not had constipation, diarrhea, abdominal pain, pain with defecation or mucous in stools. Family history is notable for the biological father who has vascular malformations. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 100/62 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On examination, the child appears pale with several dilated blood vessels visible on the cheeks bilaterally. Abdominal examination is normal. No hemorrhoids are visible on rectal examination. Fecal occult blood test is positive, and the rest of the laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is likely associated with this patient’s underlying condition? 

 Laboratory value      Results      
 Hemoglobin       9 gm/dL     
 Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)      72 fL     
 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH)      23 pg     
 Red cell distribution width (RDW)      51 fL     
 Platelets       170,000 /μL     
 Prothrombin time (PT)      11     
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (PTT)      28
questions.solution:
The patient presents with melena and is found to have a family history of vascular malformations, telangiectasias on exam, microcytic hypochromic anemia, and a positive fecal occult blood test. Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) is the most likely diagnosis. The common complications of HHT include еpiѕtахis, gastrointestinal bleeding, and iron deficiency anemia.        

Several types of vascular malformations can lead to gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding in pediatric patients, including hemangiomas, blue rubber bleb nevus syndrome, gastric antral ectasia, and hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia.       

Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT) (also called Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome) refers to an autosomal dominant vascular disorder associated with mucocutaneous telangiectasia, epistaxis, GI bleeding, and arteriovenous malformations. Arteriovenous malformations may affect many parts of the body. Patients may present with melena and hematemesis. GI bleeding in HHT typically causes iron deficiency anemia as seen in this patient.    

Option Analysis

❌ Eczema  :
Incorrect: Eczema may be seen in infants with cow milk protein allergy, which can present with vomiting, abdominal pain, blood and mucous in stool, and diarrhea. This patient most likely has hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia associated with epistaxis.  
✅ Epistaxis  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Jaundice  :
Incorrect: Jaundice may be seen in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding from liver disease. The findings of melena, gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding, family history, and telangiectasias in this patient are more consistent with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, which is associated with epistaxis.  
❌ Petechiae  :
Incorrect: Petechiae can be seen in patients with Henoch-Schönlein purpura, which presents purpuric rash, abdominal pain, and hematuria. The findings of melena and telangiectasias in this patient are more consistent with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, associated with epistaxis.  
❌ Pyoderma gangrenosum  :
Incorrect: Pyoderma gangrenosum may be seen in patients with Crohn disease, which presents with vomiting, abdominal pain, blood and mucous in stool, and diarrhea. The findings of melena and telangiectasias in this patient are more consistent with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, associated with epistaxis.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of large-volume bright red blood per rectum for 4 hours and lethargy. A caregiver reports that the bleeding began suddenly and soaked through two diapers. There is no history of fever, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea, trauma, or recent illness. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), blood pressure is 66/34 mmHg, heart rate is 142 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 34 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The extremities are cool with a capillary refill time of 4 seconds. Abdominal examination reveals no tenderness or guarding. There are no visible anal fissures or signs of external trauma. A chaperoned digital rectal examination reveals bright red blood. Initial laboratory studies are displayed below. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

 Laboratory Value Result
 Hemoglobin 6.8 g/dL
 Hematocrit 23%
 Platelet count 310,000/µL
 White blood cell count 12,000/µL
 Blood urea nitrogen 7 mg/dL
 Creatinine 0.6 mg/dL
 Prothrombin time (PT) 12.1 seconds
 Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) 33 seconds

choices.text: Intravenous (IV) fluids and transfusion of packed red blood cells (RBCs)

questions.solution:
This child presents with large-volume hematochezia, severe anemia, and hemodynamic instability, as evidenced by hypotension, tachycardia, and delayed capillary refill. The sudden onset of painless, bright red rectal bleeding in a well-nourished toddler without fever, diarrhea, or abdominal pain is suggestive of Meckel diverticulum, the most common cause of significant lower gastrointestinal bleeding in this age group. The immediate priority is fluid resuscitation with isotonic crystalloids and transfusion of packed red blood cells to restore oxygen delivery and maintain tissue perfusion.

The ABCDE approach to acute hematochezia in pediatric patients emphasizes systematic assessment and stabilization. Management begins with securing the airway, assessing breathing, and supporting circulation. Intravenous access should be established promptly, and fluid resuscitation and blood transfusion should be initiated in children with signs of shock. Continuous vital sign monitoring is essential, and supplemental oxygen should be administered if indicated. Children with brisk gastrointestinal bleeding can deteriorate rapidly, so close monitoring for signs of hemorrhagic shock, such as tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension, is critical.

Option Analysis

❌ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD):
Incorrect: Endoscopy can help identify and treat gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly from upper sources. However, it is not appropriate as the initial step in an unstable patient. Stabilization must precede diagnostic procedures.  
✅ Intravenous (IV) fluids and transfusion of packed red blood cells (RBCs):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fecal occult blood testing:
Incorrect: Occult blood testing is unnecessary when gross blood is visible on examination. In the setting of hemodynamic instability and anemia, immediate resuscitation is essential.
❌ Intravenous (IV) proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy:
Incorrect: PPIs are indicated for suspected upper gastrointestinal bleeding, which can present with hematochezia in cases of brisk bleeding. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable, and IV fluid resuscitation and transfusion take precedence.
❌ Observation and monitoring:
Incorrect: Observation alone is inappropriate for a patient with signs of shock. Immediate fluid resuscitation and transfusion are necessary to prevent clinical deterioration.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for follow-up after elevated liver enzyme levels were found on routine blood work. The patient has type II diabetes mellitus that was diagnosed 3 years ago and is currently taking metformin. He drinks 2 beers every weekend and does not consume illicit substances. He has never traveled outside of the country. He has no family history of liver disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. His BMI is 31 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals an obese abdomen with no tenderness to palpation in any of the abdominal quadrants. Laboratory testing for viral hepatitis yields the following results:



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for the management of this patient’s elevated liver enzyme levels?

choices.text: Initiation of ledipasvir and sofosbuvir therapy

questions.solution:
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a condition wherein hepatic steatosis develops in individuals who drink little or no alcohol. It is the most common cause of incidental elevations in serum transaminases, and most individuals with steatosis are asymptomatic. NAFLD most commonly occurs in patients with metabolic syndrome, which consists of hypertension, hyperglycemia, insulin resistance, and dyslipidemia. NAFLD initially begins as steatosis (fatty infiltration), and it can progress to active steatohepatitis (fatty infiltration and inflammation) and then cirrhosis; however, the incidence of progression is low.  

Risk factors for NAFLD include obesity and insulin resistance; both of these factors increase the mobilization of free fatty acids from adipose tissue, which are eventually taken up by hepatocytes. As intrahepatic lipids and their metabolic intermediates accumulate, hepatocytes become sensitized to the toxic effects of inflammatory cytokines. Additionally, the accumulation of lipid metabolism byproducts increases the production of reactive oxygen species, which disrupt mitochondrial function, cause liver injury, and trigger stellate cell activation.  

A liver biopsy would show hepatocellular lipid accumulation, with various degrees of inflammatory infiltrates, depending on the stage of the disease. Treatment is directed towards weight reduction and reversal of insulin resistance, as these are the primary drivers of NAFLD.  


Image reproduced from



Option Analysis

✅ Education on weight loss strategies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initiation of ledipasvir and sofosbuvir therapy:
Incorrect: Ledipasvir and sofosbuvir are medications commonly used to treat chronic hepatitis C (HCV) infection. This patient is negative for anti-HCV antibodies and has no history of HCV risk factors (e.g. IV drug use). Hence, it is unlikely this patient has an underlying HCV infection.
❌ No intervention:
Incorrect: While this patient’s hepatitis viral testing indicates that he does not have active viral hepatitis, his weight and diabetes mellitus suggest that his elevated liver enzymes could be due to nonalcoholic fatty liver disease. Counseling that could lead to weight reduction could prevent progression and even reverse his NAFLD.
❌ Initiation of tenofovir:
Incorrect: Tenofovir can be used to treat patients with chronic hepatitis B infection. This patient tested negative for the hepatitis B surface antigen and positive for the surface antibody, indicating that this patient has either recovered from a past infection or has been vaccinated.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of joint pains in her arms and legs, which have been going on for the past three months. She is an avid tennis player, and the pain has been interfering with her practice. She has also been feeling more fatigued and experienced a loss of libido over this same time period. Her last menstrual period was 12 years ago. She recently traveled to Costa Rica with her partner where they ate local food. Vitals are within normal limits. Her BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination shows diffuse tanning of her skin. Her skin is cool and dry. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the costal margin and is mildly tender to palpation. Laboratory studies are as follows:



After confirming the diagnosis, which of the following is the most appropriate therapy?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman is presenting with arthralgias, hypothyroidism, bronze pigmentation, and elevated glucose levels. Her laboratory testing demonstrates an elevated serum iron and ferritin but reduced total iron binding capacity. In combination, these findings are suggestive of hereditary hemochromatosis (HH), which can be treated with iron chelators and intermittent phlebotomy.  

Hemochromatosis is characterized by a mutation in the HFE gene, which results in uncontrolled small bowel reabsorption of iron. Since accumulation of iron takes many years, women generally present after menopause because during the pre-menopausal years, menstrual bleeding helps slow down iron accumulation.  

Identifying and diagnosing HH early in the disease course is imperative because treatment is highly effective and can prevent many of the disease’s complications, which occur secondary to significant iron accumulation. Initial diagnostic tests include iron studies, which would demonstrate high serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin percent saturation. Further diagnostic studies include testing for common HFE mutations, especially in patients with a family history of HH. Treatment consists of reducing iron in the body with phlebotomy and iron chelators like deferasirox, deferoxamine, and deferiprone.  



Option Analysis

✅ Chelation therapy and intermittent phlebotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nucleoside analog therapy:
Incorrect: Nucleoside/nucleotide analogs (e.g., tenofovir, entecavir) are used in patients with chronic hepatitis B infection who have decompensated liver disease. Although this patient has hepatomegaly and right upper quadrant pain, her constellation of symptoms (e.g., arthralgias, hypothyroidism, bronze pigmentation) are not adequately explained by chronic hepatitis B alone.
❌ Metformin and weight reduction:
Incorrect: Metformin and weight reduction are the first-line treatments for diabetic patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). Although this patient has an elevated glucose level, her normal BMI and constellation of additional symptoms (e.g., bronze pigmentation, hypothyroidism, elevated ferritin) suggest hemochromatosis as the cause of her underlying liver disease, for which targeted therapy with chelation and phlebotomy is more appropriate.
❌ Anti-hepatitis A virus immunoglobulins:
Incorrect: Acute viral hepatitis caused by hepatitis A typically presents as fever, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, tender hepatomegaly, and jaundice. In patients already infected, supportive care is typically all that is required for a full recovery. In patients over the age of 40 who have been exposed and not vaccinated, anti-HAV immunoglobulins may be indicated.
❌ Supplementation of underproduced hormones:
Incorrect: Hypopituitarism can result in decreased endocrine function of various organs, such as the thyroid and adrenal glands. In some cases, it may be necessary to administer exogenous hormones to supplement the underproduced hormones. However, this patient’s symptoms are more consistent with those of hemochromatosis. Treating her underlying hemochromatosis with iron chelators and phlebotomy can potentially reverse her endocrine symptoms (e.g., fatigue, decreased libido) as well.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to confusion. He has not had fevers, vomiting, diarrhea, or epigastric pain. His last colonoscopy was 5 years ago and was notable for benign polyps, which were subsequently resected. Past medical history includes hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease and type 2 diabetes. He has been drinking a half-pint of vodka daily for 30 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, BMI is 20 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals erythematous palms. Abdominal distension and shifting dullness is noted on abdominal examination. Neurologic examination is notable for flapping tremors and impaired recent and remote memory. Fecal occult blood test is positive. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of the most appropriate pharmacological agent in this patient?

choices.text: Promoting colonization with acid-resistant, non-urease producing bacteria
Increase peristalsis by stimulating enteric nerves
Inhibition of the parietal cell H+/ATPase pump

questions.solution:
Encephalopathy and ascites in the setting of chronic alcohol use are symptoms that are suggestive of a diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy (HE) precipitated by gastrointestinal bleeding (positive fecal occult blood test) in the setting of long-standing liver cirrhosis.

HE occurs since liver dysfunction results in insufficient elimination and subsequent accumulation of metabolic products (e.g. ammonia). As ammonia accumulates, it is able to cross the blood-brain-barrier, resulting in astrocyte swelling, dysfunction, and impaired neurotransmitter synthesis. Anything that increases ammonia production or reabsorption in the gut can trigger HE. These include gastrointestinal bleeding, constipation, or infections.

HE presents with symptoms like insomnia or hypersomnia, mood changes, along with confusion, and even coma in some cases. Asterixis, a flapping tremor of the hand that appears when the wrist is extended, is commonly seen.

Treatment for hyperammonemia includes lactulose, rifaximin, and detection and correction of precipitating factors:
  •  Lactulose is the first line treatment for overt hepatic encephalopathy, and its mechanism of action involves lowering the colonic pH, which allows the conversion of intraluminal ammonia to ammonium ions (non-absorbable form). As a result, use of lactulose reduces plasma ammonia levels.  
  •  Antibiotics like rifaximin have also been shown to be effective in the treatment of hepatic encephalopathy. It reduces plasma ammonia levels by altering GI flora and, in turn, reduces ammonia production intraluminally.

Option Analysis

✅ Lower colonic pH:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Promoting colonization with acid-resistant, non-urease producing bacteria:
Incorrect: Probiotics are premade formulations of microorganisms that have beneficial properties for the host, especially involving gastrointestinal health. Experimental data shows probiotic therapy favors intestinal colonization with non-ammonia producing bacteria. However, probiotics would be ineffective in treating acute hepatic encephalopathy.
❌ Inhibition of splanchnic vasodilation:
Incorrect: Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, works by inhibiting splanchnic vasodilation. It is used in patients presenting acutely with esophageal variceal hemorrhage, as it has the ability to reduce splanchnic blood flow.
❌ Increase peristalsis by stimulating enteric nerves:
Incorrect: Stimulant laxatives, such as bisacodyl, increase intestinal peristalsis by neural stimulation. Use of laxatives is contraindicated in hepatic encephalopathy, as dehydration and hypovolemia can precipitate and exacerbate HE.
❌ Inhibition of the parietal cell H+/ATPase pump:
Incorrect: Pantoprazole, a proton pump inhibitor, is indicated in the treatment of peptic ulcer disease. This patient does have a history of GERD; however, clinical features such as ascites, palmar erythema and encephalopathy suggests that cirrhosis with portal hypertension is the more likely cause of his hematemesis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to yellowing of the skin for the past few days. The patient is very fatigued and has difficulty providing a history. Temperature is 37.5ºC (99.5ºF), pulse is 84/min, blood pressure is 123/78 mmHg, respiratory rate is 14/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 98% on room air. On physical examination, the patient’s skin is jaundiced and the spleen is enlarged. Serum hemoglobin is 9.7 g/dL. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows no abnormal hemoglobin. The peripheral smear shows hyperchromic dense erythrocytes without central pallor. Which of the following historical elements is likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Family history of severe pain episodes
History of recent travel to sub-Saharan Africa

questions.solution:
Unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia is caused by one of three things: increased production of bilirubin (hemolysis), decreased hepatic uptake of bilirubin, or impaired hepatic conjugation. Hemolysis generally presents with anemia, reticulocytosis, elevated LDH, and decreased haptoglobin; and the cause of hemolysis can be determined from the peripheral smear and electrophoresis studies.

Spherocytes seen on peripheral smear indicate either autoimmune hemolytic anemia or hereditary spherocytosis. If this patient reported a family history of hemolytic anemia, then hereditary spherocytosis would likely be the cause of her current condition. The direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test can differentiate between these two conditions. A positive Coombs test indicates that the hemolysis is immune-mediated. A positive Coombs test can also indicate acute hemolytic transfusion reaction if recent blood products were transfused.

If schistocytes are seen on the peripheral smear of a patient with hemolytic anemia, then microangiopathic hemolysis (e.g. thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) or mechanical destruction (e.g. heart valve replacement) should be suspected. Other cause of hemolysis that may be determined from peripheral smear include sickle cell disease where sickle cells may be seen (confirmed with hemoglobin electrophoresis), G6PD deficiency where Heinz bodies and bite cells may be seen, and babesiosis and malaria where intracellular organisms may be seen on the peripheral smear.  

Option Analysis

❌ History of episodic jaundice:
Incorrect: Patients with Gilbert syndrome typically have a personal history of episodic jaundice and mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. This patient’s splenomegaly and spherocytes instead suggest hereditary spherocytosis.  
❌ History of aortic valve replacement:
Incorrect: An aortic valve replacement can lead to mechanical hemolytic anemia, which would lead to schistocytes on peripheral smear. This patient instead has spherocytes on the peripheral smear.  
✅ Family history of hemolytic anemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Family history of severe pain episodes:
Incorrect: Severe pain episodes are seen in sickle cell disease. The normal hemoglobin electrophoresis rules this out, and the peripheral smear shows spherocytes rather than sickle erythrocytes.  
❌ History of recent travel to sub-Saharan Africa:
Incorrect: This would be associated with malaria: an infection due to the Plasmodium species, which is endemic in many areas of sub-Saharan Africa. This patient has spherocytes on peripheral smear, indicating hereditary spherocytosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of progressive abdominal distension for the past 5 months. The patient has also noticed severe diffuse itching and has been told that her eyes look yellow. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and a “viral infection of the liver” 15 years ago for which the patient did not pursue medical treatment. The patient has not seen a physician in several years and does not take any medications. Temperature is 36.9 ºC (98.5 °F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 118/72 mmHg. On examination, the patient is jaundiced with multiple skin excoriations on the extremities and abdomen. The abdomen is distended with a positive fluid wave. Which of the following additional findings would most support this patient’s underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with progressive abdominal distension, pruritus, and jaundice indicates decompensated cirrhosis complicated by ascites. The history of an untreated “viral infection of the liver” suggests chronic hepatitis C or B as the etiology.

Certain physical exam findings suggest underlying cirrhosis. These include palmar erythema, gynecomastia, and spider angiomas. Spider angiomas are dilated blood vessels near the skin’s surface. Jaundice is also frequently seen in cirrhosis (especially as it progresses) but is not specific to cirrhosis. Spider angiomas are composed of a central arteriole surrounded by smaller vessels and are usually found on the trunk and face.
 

This image was reproduced from Wikimedia commons

The history and physical exam can also reveal complications of cirrhosis. Patients with abdominal distension and a fluid wave likely have ascites. Fever with abdominal pain and distension suggest spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Patients presenting with hematemesis may have variceal bleeding. Hepatic encephalopathy should be suspected in a patient presenting with altered mental status and a flapping tremor (asterixis).  

Option Analysis

✅ Spider angiomas:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Skin tags:
Incorrect: Skin tags can occur without any underlying cause and can also be seen in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. While this patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus, skin tags are not associated with cirrhosis.  
❌ Acanthosis nigricans:
Incorrect: Acanthosis nigricans is a dark discoloration of the skin that can be seen in diabetes mellitus. While it may be present in this patient due to untreated diabetes mellitus type 2, this patient’s presentation likely indicates cirrhosis.  
❌ Heberden nodes:
Incorrect: Heberden nodes are bony swellings seen on finger joints in patients with arthritis. If they are present, Heberden nodes are not related to cirrhosis.  
❌ S4 on cardiac auscultation:
Incorrect: S4 sound on cardiac auscultation indicates reduced ventricular compliance and results from conditions like long-standing hypertension that can lead to ventricular hypertrophy. This patient’s presentation is more likely related to cirrhosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of diffuse abdominal pain. The pain started two days ago and has been getting worse. The patient has also had subjective fevers, nausea, and clay-colored stools. Past medical history is significant for cirrhosis from primary biliary cholangitis (formerly primary biliary cirrhosis) and hypothyroidism. Temperature is 38.2 ºC (100.8 °F), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 110/68 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination the patient is jaundiced. Cardiac and pulmonary auscultation is normal. The abdomen is distended with tenderness to palpation in all quadrants. An abdominal fluid wave is present. Which of the following should be ordered next?
questions.solution:
Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) should be suspected in this patient with known cirrhosis presenting with fever, abdominal pain, and ascites. Ascites and SBP are both major complications of cirrhosis, meaning this patient has decompensated cirrhosis. Other complications include variceal hemorrhage, hepatocellular carcinoma, hepatic encephalopathy, and hepatorenal syndrome. Patients with cirrhosis who have not developed major complications are classified as having compensated cirrhosis.

The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient would be to perform an ultrasound-guided paracentesis for ascitic fluid evaluation. This patient with suspected SBP should be started on antibiotics as soon as possible after blood cultures, and ascitic fluid cell count and cultures have been collected. The most common causes of SBP are intestinal bacteria such as E. coli and Klebsiella, so antibiotics such as ceftriaxone are often used. An elevated ascitic fluid cell count with >250/mm3 neutrophils (also called polymorphonuclear cells (PMN)), especially if there is a positive fluid culture, confirms the diagnosis of SBP. Antimicrobial prophylaxis for SBP is recommended in hospitalized patients with cirrhosis who have had a prior episode of SBP, a history of variceal bleeding, and ascites with ascitic fluid protein <1.5 g/dL along with either impaired renal function or hepatic failure.

Option Analysis

✅ Ultrasound-guided paracentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ CT of the abdomen:
Incorrect: This patient with cirrhosis presents with fever, abdominal pain, and ascites. Given the history of cirrhosis and fluid wave on exam, the patient must be evaluated for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis via testing of ascitic fluid samples. Further imaging before paracentesis is not necessary.  
❌ MRI of the abdomen:
Incorrect: This patient with cirrhosis presents with fever, abdominal pain, and ascites. Given the cirrhosis and fluid wave on exam, the patient must be evaluated for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis via testing of ascitic fluid samples. Further imaging before paracentesis is not necessary.  
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient with cirrhosis is at risk for developing bleeding gastroesophageal varices, which often present with dark, tarry stools (melena) or hematemesis. This patient has clay-colored stools caused by elevated bilirubin.  
❌ Empiric antibiotics:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is very concerning for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. While antibiotics are indicated for treatment, obtaining ascitic fluid samples for culture before starting antibiotics is most appropriate.

questions.solution:
This patient with alcohol use disorder who presents with RUQ abdominal pain, elevated transaminases, and jaundice, has a clinical picture that is concerning for alcohol-induced hepatitis. When the diagnosis is clear, the patient’s Maddrey discriminant function (DF) or MELD score should be calculated to determine severity and treatment options. In some patients, however, comorbid medical conditions and certain medications can significantly affect the serum studies used to calculate these scores. MDF uses total bilirubin and prothrombin time. MELD score uses sodium, creatinine, total bilirubin, and INR. This patient has several lab abnormalities that can be from alcohol-induced hepatitis or from other conditions. The patient’s hyponatremia can be from hydrochlorothiazide use, and the baseline creatinine elevation may be from CKD which will affect the MELD score. This patient with elevated creatine kinase and significantly elevated AST may have statin myopathy and/or hepatopathy. The INR (and PT) are likely elevated from the warfarin.

In cases where alcohol-induced hepatitis is highly suspected, but the diagnosis cannot be made with history, physical and laboratory findings, a transjugular liver biopsy should be performed. In alcohol-induced hepatitis, pathology will show macrovesicular steatosis in a centrilobular pattern. Imaging is frequently unable to differentiate between alcohol-induced hepatitis and cirrhosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Transjugular liver biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: An abdominal ultrasound can suggest but cannot confirm or rule out alcohol-induced hepatitis. Ultrasound may show surface nodularity, increased echogenicity, and other findings.  
❌ CT of abdomen and pelvis with contrast:
Incorrect: This patient likely has alcohol-induced hepatitis, but the comorbid medical conditions and medications make interpretation of blood work difficult. If the diagnosis is in question, liver biopsy should be performed rather than CT imaging.  
❌ CT of abdomen and pelvis without contrast:
Incorrect: This patient likely has alcohol-induced hepatitis, but the comorbid medical conditions and medications make interpretation of blood work difficult. If the diagnosis is in question, a liver biopsy should be performed rather than CT imaging.  
❌ Serum indirect bilirubin:
Incorrect: This patient’s total bilirubin and direct bilirubin are already known, so we can calculate the indirect bilirubin without measuring it. This test is unnecessary.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the office because of weight gain and abdominal discomfort. The patient reports mild, diffuse abdominal discomfort for the past week and a weight gain of 10 lbs (4.5 kg) over the past month. She does not have nausea, vomiting, constipation, or diarrhea. The patient is a truck driver and has not seen a physician in years. She drinks a 6-pack of beer per night. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F), pulse is 136/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 82/51 mmHg. Physical examination shows jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, a flapping hand tremor on wrist extension, and a positive fluid wave. The portal venous pressure is 5 mmHg greater than the inferior vena cava pressure. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following secondary to her current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with ascites, flapping hand tremor, and an elevated pressure in the portal venous system (as compared to systemic venous system) is suggestive of portal hypertension.  

Portal hypertension means increased pressure in the portal venous system. It develops when there is resistance to portal blood flow and is aggravated by increased portal collateral blood flow. It is most commonly caused by liver cirrhosis but can also be caused by vascular obstruction (e.g., portal vein thrombosis, Budd-Chiari syndrome, and schistosomiasis).  

Portal hypertension leads to the formation of portosystemic shunts, which is when blood is diverted away from the portal venous system and backs up into systemic veins at the sites called portal-systemic anastomoses/porto-caval anastomosis. These include: 
  •  Lower esophagus: leads to esophageal varices, which can rupture and lead to an upper gastrointestinal bleeding. 
  •  In the rectum and anal canal: leads to hemorrhoids, which are also enlarged veins that can bleed 
  •  The veins of the anterior abdominal wall, which anastomose with the paraumbilical veins and become varicose. This looks like small snakes radiating under the skin around the umbilicus and is called caput medusae. 
Signs and symptoms of portal hypertension include palmar erythema, petechiae, ascites, anorectal varices, caput medusae, jaundice, and esophageal varices.  



Option Analysis

❌ Splenic vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: Portal hypertension can cause blood to back up into the spleen, causing congestive splenomegaly (enlarged spleen). In contrast, pancreatic inflammation can cause blood clot in the splenic vein and can cause gastric varices.  
❌ Unilateral left-sided ankle swelling:
Incorrect: Unilateral left-sided ankle swelling can result from obstruction of left common iliac vein, left external iliac vein, left femoral vein or any other vein in the lower limbs. Portal hypertension can be associated with bilateral ankle swelling.  
✅ Hemorrhoids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Varicocele:
Incorrect: Varicocele can occur in association with nutcracker syndrome. The pressure in the left renal vein becomes elevated due to the compression in the region where the vein crosses beneath the aorta and superior mesenteric artery. Pressure can be elevated in the left gonadal vein as well, leading to the development of varicocele. The gonadal vein is not a part of the portal system.  
❌ Mallory-Weiss tear:
Incorrect: Mallory-Weiss tear is characterized by longitudinal mucosal lacerations (intramural dissections) in the distal esophagus and proximal stomach that are usually associated with forceful retching. The upper gastrointestinal bleeding seen in association with portal hypertension is due to bleeding esophageal varices.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man was brought to the emergency department due to dizziness and vomiting for three days. The patient states that when he vomited, it appeared dark and grainy, similar to coffee grounds. He states that his stools have had a sticky consistency. He has not seen a doctor in 10 years. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Conjunctiva are icteric and pupils are reactive without papilledema. Abdominal exam is significant for a mildly distended abdomen with a fluid wave,  but no tenderness or guarding. Lab results show a moderately elevated AST and Alt and an elevated INR. Lab tests from his last clinic visit 10 years ago are shown below. Endoscopy reveals dilated distal esophageal veins with cherry-red spots. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

questions.solution:
This patient is exhibiting signs of portal hypertension secondary to cirrhosis of the liver caused by chronic hepatitis B infection. In patients with portal hypertension from cirrhosis, blood from the portal venous system can be shunted through the periumbilical veins into the umbilical vein and the veins of the abdominal wall. Engorgement of the vessels around the umbilicus is called caput medusae which is a sign of portal hypertension.

Portal hypertension in patients with cirrhosis can lead to esophageal varices. Patients with esophageal varices can experience vomiting of bright red blood if the bleeding is brisk, or darker “coffee ground” emesis if the blood has had time to sit in the stomach.  Melena or hematochezia can occur as the blood moves further through the GI tract.  Coagulopathy can further contribute to bleeding as patients with hepatitis B infection may have elevated PT/INR and PTT as well as thrombocytopenia.

Hepatitis B infection (HBV) will often clear spontaneously after the acute stage.  When surface antibodies do not form within the first six months of infection, the virus can remain circulating in the blood and liver leading to chronic infection.  This ongoing infection predisposes to complications including cirrhosis, liver failure, and hepatocellular carcinoma.  Patients from areas of the world where hepatitis B is endemic are at increased risk of infection as well as those who use IV drugs, practice high-risk sexual habits, receive non-sterile tattoos, or have experienced a needle-stick injury.  

Option Analysis

❌ Rigidity on abdominal exam:
Incorrect: Rigidity and guarding can be seen in acute abdominal processes including infection, bowel perforation, and injury.  Perforation of esophageal varices can occur, but the patient would likely be hemodynamically unstable and have guarding and tenderness on abdominal exam.  
❌ Courvoisier sign:
Incorrect:  Courvoisier sign occurs when the gallbladder is palpably enlarged due to bile obstruction.  
❌ Grey Turner sign:
Incorrect:  Grey Turner sign occurs when there is ecchymosis of the flank due to a retroperitoneal bleed.  Although bleeding retroperitoneal varices can occur, this patient presents with signs of bleeding within the GI tract.  
✅ Tortuous veins around the umbilicus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Left lower quadrant abdominal pain:
Incorrect: Pain in chronic hepatitis B with cirrhosis is typically in the upper quadrants, specifically the right upper quadrant.  Pain may be diffuse with ascites but isolated left lower quadrant pain would be atypical and is more likely to signal an alternate condition such as diverticulitis.

This patient who presents with an elevated alkaline phosphatase level and mild pruritus likely has cholestasis. Given normal ultrasound, the biliary obstruction is likely to be intrahepatic, making primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) likely. Patients with PBC can be asymptomatic, or they may present with fatigue, pruritus, and right upper quadrant pain.

PBC is an autoimmune disorder that affects the small and medium intrahepatic bile ducts. Autoimmune destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts leads to cholestasis. PBC is more prevalent in women, with a female-to-male ratio of 9:1. While it is often asymptomatic, patients can present with fatigue and pruritus. Fatigue is one of the most common early symptoms of the disease. As the disease progresses, patients may experience pruritus, which is due to the accumulation of bile salts in the skin. Studies have recently shown that the fatigue seems to stem from muscle mitochondrial dysfunction, due to the autoimmune destruction of mitochondria that characterizes the condition.

Physical examination findings in the early stages of PBC may be unremarkable, but as the disease progresses, signs of chronic liver disease, such as jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes) and hepatomegaly may be seen. In later stages, patients can have signs of liver cirrhosis like ascites and spider angiomata (small, spider-like blood vessels on the skin).

Typically, alkaline phosphatase levels are elevated in PBC. If they exceed 1.5 times the upper limit of normal, a positive antimitochondrial antibody (AMA) test result can establish the diagnosis without the need for a liver biopsy. The primary treatment for PBC is ursodeoxycholic acid, which is associated with histologic improvement, increased survival rates, and reduced reliance on liver transplantation.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Fatigue:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cold intolerance:
Incorrect: Cold intolerance is typically associated with hypothyroidism. While liver diseases can affect overall metabolism, cold intolerance is not a symptom of PBC.  
❌ Edema:
Incorrect: Edema may be a sign of late stage liver disease and cirrhosis in PBC; however, this patient has only mild symptoms and lab work shows no evidence of significant liver damage, therefore she most likely has early-stage disease.  
❌ Epigastric pain radiating to the back:
Incorrect: This type of pain is more indicative of gastrointestinal conditions like pancreatitis or peptic ulcer disease. PBC primarily affects the liver and does not typically cause this specific pattern of abdominal pain, although some patients may experience intermittent right upper quadrant abdominal pain.  
❌ Exertional chest pain:
Incorrect: Exertional chest pain is commonly associated with cardiac conditions, such as angina pectoris, resulting from reduced blood flow to the myocardium. It is not a symptom typically associated with PBC, which primarily involves the liver and biliary tract.

A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. There is no family history of hypercoagulable states. The patient has no significant past medical history and takes no medication. He does not drink alcohol. Temperature is 37℃ (98.6℉), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 142/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, there is mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without hepatosplenomegaly or evidence of an abdominal mass. Laboratory studies are shown below. Bedside ultrasound reveals hyperechoic material in the portal vein with impaired blood flow. No hepatic masses are observed. Which of the following tests should be performed to identify the likely underlying condition?  

 Laboratory Test  Result 
 Hemoglobin  18.1 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  54% 
 AST  19 
 ALT  30
questions.solution:
This patient's markedly elevated hemoglobin and hematocrit levels, along with a new diagnosis of portal vein thrombosis, raise suspicion of an underlying myeloproliferative neoplasm polycythemia vera. Evidence of JAK2 V617F mutation can be used to diagnose polycythemia vera.   

Portal vein thrombosis (PVT) is typically associated with cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma. However, other conditions can lead to PVT, including inherited thrombophilias and myeloproliferative disorders. Polycythemia vera is a type of myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the overproduction of red blood cells, leading to increased blood viscosity and a hypercoagulable state. PVT can be a complication of polycythemia vera. The JAK2 V617F mutation is found in the majority of patients with polycythemia vera, and it contributes to unregulated cell proliferation and consequent thrombotic risks. Evidence of JAK2 V617F mutation can be used to diagnose polycythemia vera.   

In patients with suspected PVT, imaging with contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan or Doppler ultrasound can be used to diagnose thrombosis. Doppler ultrasound typically reveals hyperechoic material within the portal vein, and associated distension of the portal vein and its tributaries. Computed tomography (CT) scans without contrast may show hyperattenuating material in the portal vein, though contrast-enhanced imaging is often needed to make the diagnosis. In addition to confirming the diagnosis of acute PVT, CT can also identify predisposing conditions (e.g. intra-abdominal infection), assess the extent of the thrombosis, and detect evidence of intestinal infarction.  

Option Analysis

❌ Antithrombin measurement:
Incorrect: Antithrombin III (ATIII) functions as an endogenous anticoagulant, inhibiting thrombin and activated clotting factors IX and X. Patients with thromboembolism and heparin resistance should be tested for antithrombin III deficiency. This patient with elevated hemoglobin and hematocrit and portal vein thrombosis (PVT) should be tested for underlying polycythemia vera.
✅ JAK2 mutation testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Protein C and S measurement:
Incorrect: Deficiencies in Protein C and S can be either inherited or acquired. Patients with deficiencies typically exhibit symptoms before the age of 50 and have a family history of thrombotic events.  This patient with elevated hemoglobin and hematocrit and portal vein thrombosis (PVT) should be tested for polycythemia vera.
❌ Alpha fetoprotein (AFP) level:
Incorrect: AFP levels are usually elevated in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), but elevated AFP is not directly associated with the development of portal vein thrombosis (PVT) in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma. This patient has no risks or evidence of HCC, rather the elevated hemoglobin and hematocrit and diagnosis of PVT point to polycythemia vera.
❌ Colonoscopy:
Incorrect: Colonoscopy is not useful to diagnose the cause of portal vein thrombosis or polycythemia vera and should not be performed in this case.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her daughter who reports that the patient has been increasingly forgetful and disoriented over the past seven days. The patient has a history of alcohol-related cirrhosis and was recently discharged from the hospital after treatment for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Over the past week, the daughter has noticed that the patient has been sleeping during the day, which is unusual for her. At times she has been difficult to arouse. The patient has also become increasingly irritable and has had trouble completing simple tasks that were previously easy for her. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. She is oriented only to person. Physical examination reveals generalized jaundice, scleral icterus, abdominal distension with shifting dullness, and spider angiomas overlying the upper chest wall. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Flapping tremor of the hands with arm extension
Exaggerated response of deep tendon reflexes
Upward extension of the big toe in response to stroking the sole of the foot
Involuntary pronation of the right arm
Increased muscle tone leading to resistance to passive movement

questions.solution:
The patient presents with altered mental status and is found to have a distended abdomen and stigmata of chronic liver disease on physical exam. These findings are consistent with hepatic encephalopathy. A key physical examination finding in patients with hepatic encephalopathy is asterixis, also known as a "flapping tremor." It can be observed when the patient extends the arms and dorsiflexes the hands, leading to irregular, coarse, non-rhythmic jerking movements. Asterixis reflects a lapse in postural tone control, which is characteristic of metabolic encephalopathies like hepatic encephalopathy.       

When evaluating a patient with suspected hepatic encephalopathy (HE) history taking should focus on recent changes in mental status, including confusion; disorientation; sleep disturbances; abnormal behavior; as well as any difficulties with attention, memory, or performing tasks of daily living. Providers should inquire about precipitating factors, such as recent infection, gastrointestinal bleeding, dehydration, and use of sedatives or diuretics. The physical examination should assess the patient’s level of consciousness, orientation, and ability to follow commands. Signs of chronic liver disease, such as jaundice, ascites, palmar erythema, spider angiomas, and muscle wasting, should be noted as this can also indicate the severity of underlying liver disease. Neurological examination should focus on detecting asterixis and ruling out focal neurologic deficits that may indicate other causes of altered mental status like stroke.   

Option Analysis

✅ Flapping tremor of the hands with arm extension :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Exaggerated response of deep tendon reflexes:
Incorrect: Hyperreflexia refers to an exaggerated deep tendon reflex and is more commonly associated with upper motor neuron diseases, like with stroke or spinal cord injuries. It is not a typical finding for patients with hepatic encephalopathy. However, asterixis is common with hepatic encephalopathy.  
❌ Upward extension of the big toe in response to stroking the sole of the foot:
Incorrect: The Babinski sign, characterized by dorsiflexion of the big toe and fanning of adjacent toes in response to stroking the lateral aspect of the sole, indicates dysfunction of the corticospinal tract, often due to an upper motor neuron lesion. It is typically associated with conditions like multiple sclerosis, stroke, or spinal cord injury. It is not typical with hepatic encephalopathy, which is more commonly associated with asterixis. 
❌ Involuntary pronation of the right arm :
Incorrect: Pronator drift is a test of upper motor neuron function where the patient extends the arms forward with palms up. A positive test occurs when the patient involuntarily pronates one or both arms and lowers them. It suggests a mild hemiparesis and is more specific to conditions that affect the corticospinal tract, such as stroke. 
❌ Increased muscle tone leading to resistance to passive movement:
Incorrect: Rigidity refers to increased muscle tone leading to resistance to passive movement. It is often seen in patients with extrapyramidal disorders.

A 68-year-old woman is brough to the emergency department by her family for evaluation of increasing confusion, fatigue, and abdominal distension over the past two days. Her family reports that she has been more forgetful over the past few days and has had difficulty staying awake throughout the day. The patient has a history of cirrhosis secondary to untreated hepatitis C. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is oriented only to person, and the rest of the neurologic exam is nonfocal. The abdomen is tense and mildly tender to palpation with shifting dullness and a fluid wave. The patient exhibits a flapping tremor when asked to extend their arms. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 White blood cell count     13,500/µL    
 Hemoglobin     11.2 g/dL    
 Platelet count     75,000/µL    
 Total bilirubin     3.8 mg/dL    
 AST     72 U/L    
 ALT     56 U/L    
 Serum creatinine     1.6 mg/dL    
 Ammonia     85 µg/dL

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) abdomen and pelvis with contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms consistent with overt hepatic encephalopathy (HE) and ascites, along with an elevated white blood cell count and fever, raising the suspicion for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). Prompt diagnosis of SBP via paracentesis should be made in cases of HE where SBP is a likely precipitant. Prompt administration of antibiotics (e.g. ceftriaxone) is essential to prevent further deterioration.        

SBP refers to an infection of ascitic fluid that can occur in patients with cirrhosis and is often a precipitating factor for HE. The pathogenesis involves bacteria that translocate from intestinal tissue into the ascitic fluid secondary to impaired liver function and immune dysregulation. SBP can exacerbate HE via increasing systemic inflammation and disruption of hepatic metabolism, ultimately increasing the neurotoxic effects of ammonia. While ammonia levels are often elevated in patients with HE, an elevated ammonia level is not necessary to make the diagnosis; and levels may be elevated in patients without HE.       

Covert hepatic encephalopathy (CHE) is characterized by subtle cognitive and psychomotor impairments that are not clinically apparent without specialized testing, such as psychometric tests or critical flicker frequency analysis. Patients with CHE may have mild attention deficits, memory issues, or sleep disturbances but typically maintain normal daily functioning. In contrast, patients with overt hepatic encephalopathy (OHE) present with obvious neuropsychiatric symptoms, such as confusion; disorientation; and in severe cases, stupor or coma. The transition from covert to overt encephalopathy can be suspected based on the onset of noticeable mental status changes and physical exam findings, particularly asterixis (flapping tremor of the hands), which can be identified during a routine clinical examination.   

Option Analysis

✅ Paracentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lactulose:
Incorrect: Lactulose is used to manage hepatic encephalopathy; however, the immediate priority is to rule out and treat any underlying infections, such as spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), which could have precipitated the encephalopathy. 
❌ Broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Antibiotics are essential if spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is confirmed or strongly suspected; however, the diagnosis in this stable patient should be confirmed via paracentesis prior to initiating antibiotic therapy. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) abdomen and pelvis with contrast:
Incorrect: Imaging may be useful in some cases; however, it is not the first step in managing a patient with suspected spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and encephalitis. Paracentesis is the more direct and immediate diagnostic test. Contrasted studies should be avoided in this patient with signs of acute kidney injury (e.g. elevated creatinine).  
❌ Computed tomography (CT) head without contrast :
Incorrect: A CT head without contrast is generally indicated if there is a suspicion of an intracranial process, such as a hemorrhage or stroke, which is less likely in this context where there are no focal neurologic findings. The clinical presentation of this patient is more suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), making paracentesis the appropriate next step.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with a history of cirrhosis due to chronic hepatitis B is admitted to the hospital with confusion, lethargy, and disorientation. He is diagnosed with overt hepatic encephalopathy (OHE) and started on lactulose therapy, titrated to achieve 2-3 soft stools per day. Over the next five days, his symptoms dramatically improve. Vital signs are within normal limits and his physical examination is unremarkable. He is now alert; oriented to person, place, and time; and back to his baseline cognitive function. He is tolerating a regular diet and has no new symptoms. Which of the following is the next step in management upon discharge?

choices.text: Discontinue lactulose and recommend protein restriction

questions.solution:
This patient was hospitalized for overt hepatic encephalopathy and was effectively treated with lactulose. On lactulose, he has had a return to his baseline mental status, and, therefore, should be discharged on lactulose indefinitely. Lactulose remains the cornerstone of treatment for hepatic encephalopathy (HE), even after symptoms have resolved. It helps to prevent the recurrence of encephalopathy by reducing the absorption of ammonia in the gut.       

Lactulose, a nonabsorbable disaccharide, works by lowering ammonia levels in the blood through two mechanisms: it acidifies the colon, converting ammonia to ammonium, which cannot be absorbed; and it promotes the excretion of ammonia through the stool by acting as a cathartic. Lactulose can be continued indefinitely in patients with HE who have had a good response. It is typically titrated to achieve 2-3 soft stools per day, which helps to prevent the recurrence of HE by maintaining low ammonia levels.        

The antibiotic Rifaximin is often used as an adjunct to lactulose in patients with recurrent episodes of HE despite adequate lactulose therapy. It works by reducing the population of ammonia-producing gut bacteria, thereby decreasing ammonia production. While lactulose remains the first-line treatment, rifaximin is added in cases of recurrent or persistent HE to enhance the therapeutic effects and reduce the risk of relapse.        

After adding rifaximin to the treatment regimen, the patient's response should be reassessed after 48 hours. If there is noticeable improvement in mental status, lactulose should be continued indefinitely, and rifaximin should be continued for at least three months. However, if the patient's condition does not adequately improve, it may indicate severe liver dysfunction, necessitating surgical consultation to evaluate for liver transplantation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Continue lactulose indefinitely :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Discontinue lactulose:
Incorrect: Discontinuing lactulose is inappropriate because it increases the risk of recurrent hepatic encephalopathy. Lactulose is essential for maintaining low ammonia levels and preventing future episodes of HE. This patient with HE should continue on lactulose indefinitely. 
❌ Switch to rifaximin monotherapy:
Incorrect: Rifaximin is typically used as an adjunct to lactulose in patients with recurrent episodes of HE or for those who do not respond adequately to lactulose alone. It is not used as monotherapy unless lactulose is poorly tolerated.  
❌ Add rifaximin to lactulose:
Incorrect: Adding rifaximin to lactulose is considered for patients with frequent recurrence of hepatic encephalopathy despite lactulose therapy. This patient has shown significant improvement with lactulose alone; therefore, there is no need to add rifaximin at this time. 
❌ Discontinue lactulose and recommend protein restriction:
Incorrect: Discontinuing lactulose and restricting protein intake is not recommended. Protein restriction can lead to malnutrition. Current guidelines favor maintaining adequate oral protein intake while continuing lactulose indefinitely to prevent encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the office to follow up on recent blood testing. The patient has no previously diagnosed medical conditions. The patient has been feeling more fatigued recently but attributes it to working long hours. The patient drinks 6-8 cans of beer on weekday evenings and 10-12 cans on weekend days. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6° F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 132/74 mmHg. Physical exam shows palmar erythema and spider angiomas. Neurologic examination is normal. There is no distension of the abdomen and no abdominal tenderness to palpation. Lab results are shown below. Ultrasound of the abdomen shows a small, nodular liver and minimal ascites. The patient is referred for upper endoscopy which shows medium varices with no signs of active bleeding. Which of the following medications should be started at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient presentation suggests a new diagnosis of cirrhosis. The patient currently has no complications and thus has compensated cirrhosis. Management of cirrhosis includes treating the underlying cause of cirrhosis, as well as preventing and treating complications. Once a patient has been diagnosed with cirrhosis, it is important to stage it and determine mortality risk using the Child-Pugh and Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) scores. Patients should be referred for evaluation for liver transplantation when the MELD score is greater than 10 or the patient has had signs of decompensation (e.g., variceal hemorrhage, ascites, hepatic encephalopathy).

All patients with cirrhosis should be screened with upper endoscopy (EGD) for gastroesophageal varices. Those with medium, large, or high-risk varices on endoscopy should be treated with non-selective beta-blockers and/or endoscopic band ligation for primary variceal bleeding prevention. Timing for repeat EGD is determined based on initial findings. Patients should be screened for hepatic encephalopathy at each visit by assessing neurologic function.

All patients with cirrhosis should be screened for hepatocellular carcinoma every 6 months with ultrasound. Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary malignancy in patients with cirrhosis. Cirrhosis secondary to hepatitis B and C infection is the most common risk factor.

Patients should have a paracentesis if they have new-onset moderate to severe ascites or if there is concern for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). Patients should follow a strict low sodium diet (less than 2 g daily) and should be given furosemide plus spironolactone if they have moderate to severe ascites. If patients do not respond to medications then therapeutic paracentesis should be performed.  

Option Analysis

✅ Beta-blocker:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Proton pump inhibitor:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitors are used in the management of gastroesophageal reflux disease and peptic ulcer disease, not for prevention of variceal bleeding.  
❌ Octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide is used in the management of actively bleeding gastroesophageal varices. It causes vasoconstriction and reduces inflow of blood to the portal system. This patient has medium-sized, non-bleeding varices on upper endoscopy.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a diuretic that is used to manage ascites in patients with cirrhosis. It is used in combination with spironolactone, not as monotherapy. In addition, since the patient has minimal ascites, initial management can be salt restriction and abstinence from alcohol.  
❌ Lactulose:
Incorrect: Lactulose is used in the management of hepatic encephalopathy. This patient is not presenting with neurologic signs or symptoms to support a diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy.
